name: A table lamp by the Bauhaus teacher Christian Dell, designed in the 1930s
description:
A very rare Bauhaus table lamp, documented as being Christian Dell's design, executed in brown bakelite with stepped rounded rectangular base, curved arm and adjustable asymmetric hemispherical shade.

As the master in charge of the metalwork department at the Staatliches Bauhaus in Weimar, Christian Dell (1893-1974) worked in close collaboration with other modernist luminaries such as Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, Marianne Brandt, Hin Bredendieck and Hans Przyrembel. Although also a silversmith and jeweller he is now best known as functionalist innovator and a key figure in the development of industrial lighting. His significance in the story of Twentieth Century design is becoming increasingly recognised by museum curators worldwide.

Size: About 45.5 cm (18 inches) in height.

Condition: Excellent, with only the most minor signs of age and use to the surface of the bakelite. There are no damages such as splits, cracks or dents, just some expected loss to the reflective paint on the inside of the shade. The lamp retains its original switch and is in working order having been rewired at some point in the recent past with a modern Continental European 2-pin plug. However all vintage electrical items must be safety-checked by a qualified electrican before use. Please see my important note concerning the sale of vintage electrical items below. See my shop and visit the Bauhaus or lighting sections for more vintage modernist lamps.

Reference: See Christie's Amsterdam, The Bauhaus and the Bauhaus Designers, 26 October, 1989, lot number 446.

name: 12 Aluminium storage drawers designed for the New Frankfurt building project, 1926
description:
Background

In 1926 Ernst May invited the Austrian architect Grete Schütte-Lihotzky, who had been working with Adolf Loos in Vienna, to be a part of an ambitious project to create new settlements of affordable social housing in Frankfurt.

His New Frankfurt plan aimed to mobilise a new type of architecture - using the latest materials and construction methods - to address an acute housing shortage in the city. This had been caused by the economic crises that had gripped Germany in the aftermath of the First World War, culminating in a period of hyperinflation. 

At the centre of May’s large-scale development scheme – a project that would successfully house ten percent of the Frankfurt population in new modernist dwellings by 1930 – was Schütte-Lihotzky’s remarkably progressive fitted kitchen.

Each Frankfurt Kitchen was equipped with a stool, a gas stove, a fold-down ironing board and a concealed wastebin. 

Built-in storage was provided in the form of cupboards incorporating rows of small removable aluminium drawers, of which the one shown in this listing is a rare survivor. The drawers offered immediate access to everyday ingredients like flour (mehl) and sugar and had pull handles at the front and spouts at the back for easy pouring.

The final image is a scan of an original postcard (not included in this sale) showing an installation of the Frankfurt Kitchen at the Deutscher Werkbund's Die Wohnung expo of 1927. The event, which involved among others Behrens, Gropius, Le Corbusier, Mies Van Der Rohe and Oud, provided an opportunity for May and Schütte-Lihotzky to showcase their vision of egalitarian housing settlements to an international audience. This exposure eventually resulted in an invitation - three years later - from the Soviet Union to reproduce New Frankfurt-style developments on a truly mass scale.


Size: 

Approx 130mm wide x 160 high x 290 length


Condition: 

Good to very good indeed. As you would expect the drawers are in well used original condition. There is expected aged related wear to the surfaces and a couple of minor knocks here and there but no significant damages such as cracks or signs of restoration/repair.

The set includes 12 differently labelled storage drawers.

Text and photographs © Room 606. All rights reserved.

name: A complete set of hyperinflation banknotes designed inside the Bauhaus by Herbert Bayer, 1923
description:
An extremely rare chance to acquire a note in each denomination and colour. 

Herbert Bayer attended the Weimar Bauhaus as a pupil from 1921 to 1923, at the time the economic crisis in post-WW1 Weimar was developing and reaching its dramatic peak.

He initially took Johannes Itten's revolutionary Preliminary Course on colour and form, then moved on to study mural painting with Wassily Kandinsky and Oskar Schlemmer.

It was at this time that he created the Universal alphabet; the lower-case only typography now synonymous with the Bauhaus and its powerful legacy.

In 1923 he was also commissioned by the Thüringian State in Weimar to design the new high value banknotes. The impoverished Weimer Republic government was desperately producing emergency money - increasingly high single note denominations - in an attempt to combat acute hyper-inflation.

Bayer returned to the Bauhaus in 1925 - now located at Dessau - as teacher, to lead a new course in advertising and typography. He remained a tutor there until 1928, the same year Bauhaus founder Walter Gropius departed.

LITERATURE An illustration of the banknote can be found in the catalogue for the famous 50 Years of the Bauhaus exhibition, which was held at the Royal Academy in London in 1968, on page 118.

CONDITION The notes are in very good circulated condition with some wear and marking consistent with age and use but no damages or repairs. Each note measures approx. 9.1 cm x 14.4 cm.

Text and photos Copyright © Matthew Grice 2013

name: A  table lamp by the Bauhaus teacher Christian Dell, 1930s
description:
This lamp was designed by Dell for the Kaiser company in the 1930s. It's an uncommon slight variant of Dell's Model 6607, having a thinner and longer cylindrical wooden grip handle on the upright.

As the master in charge of the metalwork department at the Staatliches Bauhaus in Weimar, Christian Dell (1893-1974) worked in close collaboration with other modernist luminaries such as Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, Marianne Brandt, Hin Bredendieck and Hans Przyrembel. Although also a silversmith and jeweller he is now best known as functionalist innovator and a key figure in the development of industrial lighting. His significance in the story of twentieth century design is becoming increasingly recognised by museums and leading auction houses worldwide.

Executed in black lacquered steel and chrome with painted wooden handle. The tubular steel upright is extendible to allow different heights and the shade can rotate through 360 degrees. It is stamped Kaiser Idell Original to the shade. The word Idell was an amalgam of Dell and idee, connoting a 'Christian Dell idea'.

Size: About 570 mm in total height. The shade's diameter is about 160 mm and the diameter of the base is approx. 165 mm.

Condition: The lamp is in very good unrestored condition with wear to the  surface of the lacquer in places consistent with age and use but no significant damages such cracks or splits to the metal or signs of corrosion . As you can see, it displays beautifully. The surface wear is highlighted in the close-up photos that I have provided below. The silvered interior of the shade is in very good condition.  The lamp retains its original switch but has had all vintage wiring removed for safety reasons, so it will required professional rewiring before use.

References:

See Phillips de Pury & Company New York, 20-21st Century Design Art (Sale No. NY050205), December 8, 2005, lot 44 for  a similar (model 6007) Christian Dell lamp. Estimate $1200 - 1400.

Also Sotheby's New York, 20th Century Design (Sale No. N08721), March 10, 2011, Lot 107

Der Arbeit zu Nutz' - den Augen zum Schutz! Kaiser Idell, Arbeits-Leuchten Nr. 6, brochure, 1930s, p. 3

name: Braun | Die Letzte Edition (The Last Edition)
description:
A folder containing 16 prints and other materials to commemorate Braun’s hi-fi range.

Published in limited numbers to mark the end of hi-fi production at Braun in 1990.

Includes a superb series of 16 six-colour metallic offset lithographic prints of classic Braun hi-fi products. All but one of these items were either designed or co-designed by Dieter Rams.

The prints and accompanying materials are housed in a black clam shell box. Even the box itself and its contents were designed by Rams himself.

The folio consists of:

• A contents sheet

• A 12-page illustrated pamphlet on the Atelier range 1979 - 1991

• 16 metallic six-colour off-set lithographic prints of audio designs for Braun

• Each print comes with a corresponding off-set litho print of the original design sketch for that item, executed in grey ink on tracing paper. These can be overlaid on the print to create a new image.

• The prints depict the following items: the SK 4 Phono super (1956); TP 1 Phono-Transistor (1959); Studio 2 Stereo (1959); LE 1 loudspeaker (1959); Atelier 3 compact system with record player (1962); PS 45 turntable  (1962); TC 20 record player (1963); T 1000 Worldreceiver (1963); TS 45 steuergerat (1964); TG 60 Reel to Reel, (1965); L450 Flat Speaker (1965); CSV 250 tuner(1956); Regie 308 (1973); RS 1/PC 1 Integral Studio System (1978); MS 2150 Studiomaster loudspeaker (1979) Atelier system (1980).

• A further 3 prints – macro shots of items from the hi-fi range.

• 5 more pages with text. Four of these are printed on tracing paper.

All of the items in the folio measure approximately 31 cm x 31 cm. All of the text is in German.

Condition:  Excellent with minimal signs of careful handling. The prints are of truly excellent quality, executed in 5 metallic colours. Each would look fabulous framed. This is a stunning, rare collectors’ item – not to be missed.

name: The Street Markets of London w/ photos by Moholy-Nagy
description:
The Street Markets of London by Mary Benedetta 

Illustrated with 64 stunning full-page reproductions of photographs by Bauhaus photographer Laszlo Moholy-Nagy

John Miles Ltd., London, 1936

First edition

Format: 8vo, with 201 pages and 64 photographic plates


Mary Benedetta offers a fabulous idiosyncratic account of London markets of the immediate pre-war period in London, complete with pen portraits of myriad characters that she encountered. Among the locations featured are Petticoat Lane, Farringdon Street, Caledonian Market, Brixton, Covent Garden, Berwick Market, Shepherd's Bush, Brick Lane, Billingsgate and Commercial Road.

The book includes 64 full-page sepia reproductions of photographs by László Maholy-Nagy. Aside from these trademark atmospheric and dynamic images, the legendary Bauhaus artist / photographer also contributes a short but fascinating introduction.

A Hungarian, Moholy-Nagy spent five years at the Bauhaus having been appointed a master by Walter Gropius. He wrote two of the books for the famous Bauhausbucher series, which he co-edited with Gropius: Malerei Fotographie Film (Painting Photography Film) and Von Material zu Architecture (published in English as The New Vision).

He stayed in London between 1935 and 1937 after the Nazis had forced the closure of the Bauhaus a year earlier. He went on to found the New Bauhaus in Chicago.

The Street Markets of London is one of just three books Moholy worked on during his time in the UK. At the time of listing I also have another of these publications - Eton Portrait by Bernard Fergusson - for sale in another auction.

Condition: An excellent copy, beautifully professionally re-bound in green cloth. Internally it is very clean and bright, save for a small brown mark on the title page. The Moholy-Nagy photographs are absolutely stunning.  There is the bookbinder's book-plate but no previous owners' inscriptions or dustjacket.

name: 50 years of the Bauhaus Exhibition Catalogue, 1968
description:
50 Years of the Bauhaus

The original catalogue for the first major retrospective on the Bauhaus, held at the Royal Academy in London in September and October 1968.
 
Language: English
 
Size: 225 mm by 225 mm
 
Softback in paper wrappers. The vibrant cover was designed by Herbert Bayer.


This rare and stylish volume is a fantastic resource for collectors and enthusiasts, with 367 pages divided into 8 sections (with 7 coloured division sheets) covering every aspect of the famous design school's teaching and its output.

The majority of the pages are given over to black and white and colour illustrations of work, which are too numerous to count.

Those featured include Walter Gropius, Marianne Brandt, Christian Dell, Herbert Bayer, Hans Przyrembel, Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, Wilhelm Wagenfeld and Marcel Breuer among many more.

There are also introductory essays by Ludwig Grote, Walter Gropius, Sigfried Giedion & Hans M. Wingler among others.

This is a very good copy. There is some edgewear to the covers and a neat original owner's inscription on the front endpaper, dated '68. Internally it is excellent; very clean and bright with sound binding. This volume is heavy for a softcover book and binding can be notoriously fragile.

name: Die Nibelungen dem Deutschen Volke, interpreted by Franz Keim, 1920
description:
Gerlach's Jugendbücherei: Band 22

Gerlach and Wiedling, Vienna and Leipzig, 1920 (Second Edition)

Illustrations, typography, vignettes and book design by Carl Otto Czeschka

67 pages with 8 double page illustrations in blue, red, gold and black. Also many vignettes in black and white.

Hardcover in tan boards with title vignettes on the front and spine

Without dustwrapper (as originally issued)

Size approx. 15 cm by 14 cm


This stunning work is one of the publications of Art Nouveau. Czeschka, a leading member of the Vienna Secession, studied at the Vienna School of Arts and Crafts before designing for the Wiener Werkstätte. He worked in variety of media including jewellery, metalwork, textiles, furniture as well as book design.
 
References:

There is an identical second edition copy of this book held in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art in New York. For illustrations and more information visit the MoMA.org website and search for object number '9561'.

Condition:

The condition is very good. There is expected light browning to the covers and a small watermark on the front at the bottom and a previous owner's inscription (dated 1924) on the front end paper. There is a little expected minor wear to the board edges. Internally, the pages are all very clean and bright and gold detailing in the illustrations is vibrant. There is some minor creasing to the top corner of the final dozen or so leaves of the book, but in my opinion this is not distracting.

Text and photographs © copyright room_606 (2012). All rights reserved.

name: A set of three HLD 4 Hair Dryers designed by Dieter Rams for Braun, 1970
description:
With ABS plastic housings in the three primary colours: red, blue and yellow

Size approx. 140 mm x 85 x 50


Another timeless design classic from Dieter Rams and Braun. The HLD 4's dryer mechanism is incredibly compact even by today's standards, housed within a rounded rectangle shape. 

The parallel slits on the front pleasingly recall the same designer's famous SK 4 record player of 1956, while the white dot on the circular rocker switch softens the pared down austerity of the overall design.

When launched in 1970 it was available in the three primary colours - a feature that helped to make it as popular with consumers back then as it does with collectors now.

The hair dryers are in excellent vintage used condition and working (please see note below). 

They have only very minor surface signs of use consistent with decades of careful use – there are no cracks or signs of repair. Please scroll to the bottom of this page for more photos.

The hair dryers retain their original continental European 2-pin plugs. 

There are several important things to note about functionality. Please read them carefully as they constitute a condition of sale.

Most importantly, as is the case with all vintage electrical items, the hair driers are sold here as museum-quality DECORATIVE ITEMS ONLY, without any guarantee of functionality or safe use.

Because of their age and the variation in international electrical standards, the are definitely NOT intended for use. It would be the buyer's responsibility alone to ensure that they were fully safety checked by a qualified electrician before they ever being plugged into the mains.

References

See Keiko Ueki-Polet and Klaus Kemp, Less and More: The Design Ethos of Dieter Rams, Gestalten Press, Berlin, 2009, pp254-257 

Also Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, pp 321 for illustrations and more information.

Text and photographs © Room 606. All rights reserved.

name: Braun DW 30 digital watch by Dieter Rams and Dietrich Lubs, 1978
description:
Brushed steel rectangular case with original leather strap

Size approx. 33 x 36 x 8 mm

Complete with all original packaging and documents

The carton SIGNED by Dieter Rams


This is a true twentieth century design icon. Designed by Dieter Rams and Dietrich Lubs in 1978, the DW 30 is an early example of the digital watch and a shining example of Braun's Bauhaus-tradition design.

Even the strap exudes functional minimalist perfection – it is attached to the body of the watch by means of four cross-headed screws that are incorporated into a metal strip.

The watch was only produced until 1981 and this is one of only 3000 ever made, making this is an extremely rare and highly sought-after item. 

Only a handful have appeared in modern design sales in the top London auction houses over the past decade or so.



Condition:

The watch is in excellent condition with minimal surface signs of age and wear but no significant damages or signs of repair. As good as you are ever likely to find.

All of the watch's original functions still work - pressing the side buttons cause the light to come on or minutes & seconds and date to be shown. 

 

References:

Pieter Doensen, Watch: History of the Modern Wristwatch, Snoeck-Ducaju & Zoon publishers, Gent, Belgium, 1994, pp 68-69
Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, pages 212-213 and 475.  

© Text and photographs copyright room_606. Please All rights reserved.

name: A catalogue of the collection of Martinware formed by Frederick John Nettlefold 1936
description:
A Catalogue of the Collection of Martinware Formed By Mr Frederick John Nettlefold 
Together with a Short History of the Firm of R W Martin and Brothers of Southall
Charles R Beard

Privately Printed for the Owner By Waterlow & Sons, London, 1936. 

Bound in Original Brown Cloth. 

First Edition. 

252 pages and 69 plates beautifully printed on heavy, deckle-edged paper. 

This wonderful privately-printed catalogue of the work of the Martin Brothers is very rare and much sought-after. It is rare to find one is such good condition. The collection is profusely illustrated with 48 black and white illustrations on 39 plates and 33 colour illustrations on 30 plates. The images are accompanied by detailed notes on each item including where appropriate sketched facsimiles of the signature. The contents are as follows:

The Early life of R.W. Martin
R.W. Martin and Brothers
The F.J. Nettlefold Collection
Bibliography
Works Exhibited by R.W. Martin
Collections and Exhibitions
Index

The condition is very good indeed. 

Bound in original brown cloth. 

Some discreet library stamps and labels. As is always found, the heavy stock deckle-edge paper sheets are wavy and there is some bumping and general wear to the heavy board covers. Nevertheless a wonderful copy of a rare antiquarian book.

It measures roughly 40 x 30 x 5 cm (height x width x thickness)

name: Original large Sea Things serving tray by Ray Eames for Waverly Products, USA, ca. 1953
An ABK 20, or Model 4780, quartz wall clock by Dietrich Lubs for BRAUN, 1985
description:
A classic example of Braun's Bauhaus-tradition design, this piece was created by Lubs while working under the design directorship of Dieter Rams. 

It's essentially a hybrid of the slimline ABK 30 and the more substantial ABK 31, which had a clear perspex cover for the dial. In my experience it is a particularly hard-to-find model.
I particularly like the colouring of this example; it has a cream dial that is offset by black elements: outer ring, inner ring, Univers type numerals and logo and hands. 

The clock is fully factory marked both on the front of the dial and reverse. It measures approx. 20 cm in diameter and is in excellent used condition and full working order. There are only minor signs of age and use - no damages or signs of repair.

Reference

See Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, p 237 for illustration and more information.

name: A rare 1 Milliarde hyperinflation banknote designed inside the Bauhaus by Herbert Bayer in 1923
description:
Here's a chance to acquire an example of original Bauhaus typography and a wonderful survival from a dramatic moment in the history of the last century: a hyper-inflationary bank note from Weimar Germany. The largest denominations printed and are now particularly scarce and hard to come by. One milliarde was 1000000000 German Marks. In today's widely-used short scale numbering system, this would equate to 1 billion!

Herbert Bayer attended the Weimar Bauhaus as a pupil from 1921 to 1923, at the time the economic crisis in post-WW1 Weimar was developing and reaching its dramatic peak. He initially took Johannes Itten's revolutionary Preliminary Course on colour and form, then moved on to study mural painting with Wassily Kandinsky and Oskar Schlemmer. It was at this time that he created the Universal alphabet; the lower-case only typography now synonymous with the Bauhaus and its powerful legacy. In 1923 he was also commissioned by the Thuringian State in Weimar to design the new high value banknotes. The impoverished Weimer Republic government was desperately producing emergency money - increasingly high single note denominations - in an attempt to combat acute hyper-inflation.
 
Bayer returned to the Bauhaus in 1925 - now located at Dessau - as teacher, to lead a new course in advertising and typography. He remained a tutor there until 1928, the same year Bauhaus founder Walter Gropius departed.
 
For background on hyper-inflation in the Weimar Republic see Wikipedia.org: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyper_inflation
 
An illustration of the banknote can be found in the catalogue for the first Bauhaus retrospective -  '50 Years of the Bauhaus' - which was held at the Royal Academy in London in 1968. The reference is on page 118.
 
Condition: The note is in good circulated condition with some wear and marking consistent with age and use but no damages or repairs. The note measures approx. 9.1 cm x 14.4 cm.

name: THE GUILD OF HANDICRAFT Its deed of trust and rules | From library of C R Ashbee
description:
The Guild of Handicraft

Its deed of trust and rules for the guidance of its guildsmen, together with a brief note on its work carried up to the close of the year 1909 and prepared for the use of its members and for the Trustees by C.R. Ashbee

Essex House Press, 1909

Wood-engraved title-vignette and ornamental initial by Charles Robert Ashbee, original holland-backed boards, 8vo, 22 pages, 1909.
 
Limited to 100 copies, this example has a small card tipped in with the legend 'From the library of Janet Ashbee and C. R. Ashbee'. 

The book is in excellent condition, with some minor wear and browning to the extremities but no significant faults or damages. Inside I'd describe it as very crisp and bright. There is some foxing to the front and rear endpapers, some minor rippling to the rough cut pages and a neat previous owner's signature written in pencil, dated 1925 (on the f.e.p.). The signature is not completely clear, but may be that of Mr Alec. Miller, one of the first trustees and original Labour Director of the Guild of Handicraft.

Please contact me if you would like to see more photos.

name: Modernist door handles designed for the New Frankfurt building project, ca. 1929 [10 pairs avail.]
description:
A true icon of modernism, these door handles were designed for the famous Ernst May's New Frankfurt project of the mid-1920s.

Kramer had attended the Bauhaus for a year, before working for May building and furnishing the housing projects of New Frankfurt until 1930. 

He was a contributor to the second CIAM conference, which was held in Frankfurt in 1929 and was focused on promoting functionalism in architecture through an evaluation of May's work. 

In 1938 he emigrated to the United States and soon began work on a number of design projects, including  a collaboration with the visionary Norman Bel Geddes on designs for the 1939 World's Fair in New York. He also had connections with the social theorists of the Frankfurt School and worked on commissions from Theodor Adorno at Institute for Social Research during its tenure in New York.

He returned to Germany in 1947, holding the post of director of the Johann Wolfgang Goethe University of Frankfurt am Main until his retirement in 1962. (For more info seehttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferdinand_Kramer)

Materials: Nickel plated metal complete with circular lock plates 

Condition: Very good well used condition with no significant damages, but expected surface wear reflecting decades of age and use. They exhibit a beautiful patina. A fabulous rare find; don't miss this opportunity.

References: 

Both b&W illustrations are taken from Siegfried Gronert, Türdrücker der Moderne: eine Designgeschichte (Door Handles of the Modern Period: A Design History), Franz Schneider Brakel (FSB), Walter Konig Verlag, Koln, 1991 pp 26-27. The photo is an archive photo of and New Frankfurt interior showing Kramer's door handle design in situ, taken around 1930. 

Also see http://gropius-druecker.de/html/frankfurter_normendrucker.html for an illustration. This scholarly German-language website is dedicated to the history of Bauhaus door handles.

name: A pair of modernist bookends by Ruppelwerk, the design attributed to Marianne Brandt, c.1932
description:
The design of these wonderful modernist bookends in walnut and brass is strongly attributed to the Bauhaus designer Marianne Brandt, circa 1929-32.

Brandt’s association with the Ruppel factory is well-known. But her tenure at the Gotha-based company was short-lived, coming after another relatively brief assignment working at Walter Gropius’s architectural office in Berlin.

She took over control of the firm’s metal product range and was charged with updating and reviving it, but ultimately found the firm’s inveterate conservatism stifling. This is an excellent example of this firms output during this period of modernization.

Dimensions: H. 15 x 10.2 x 11.8 cm.

Condition: Very good used condition with some patination to the brass that could be improved with polishing. There are no significant damages or any signs of restoration or repair. The Ruppelwerk factory mark  - 'Ruppel geschützt' - is present but extremely faint. I have included a picture of the stamp as found on another Ruppelwerk piece - a Brandt napkin holder - for comparison.

name: Glas im Bau, Arthur Korn, 1929
description:
** This item is for sale on another website. Please contact me for more details

Glas im Bau und als Gebrauchsgegenstand | Arthur Korn


Publisher: Ernst Pollack, Berlin 
Hardback First edition
Published in 1929
254 pages, illustrated with 187 black and white photographic plates and building plans
Black cloth with gilt lettering
Text in German
Size approx 31 cm x 22 cm



This is the extremely rare first edition of Arthur Korn's important 1929 book Glas Im Bau Und Als Gerbrauchsgegenstand, a treatise on the use of glass in Bauhaus and Bauhaus-inspired architecture.

This mainly photographic survey includes work by many of the most talented European architects adopting the then evolving idiom of glazed curtain walling. It so doing it presents an essential pictorial history of the new architecture of the 1920s. 

Walter Gropius, Le Corbusier and Pierre Jeanneret, Marcel Breuer, HP Berlage, Hans and Wasssili Luckhardt, Robert Mallet-Stephens, Erich Medelsohn, Bruno Paul, Gerrit Rietveld, Ludwig Mies Van Der Rohe, Naum Gabo, Mart Stam, Hans Scharoun and Arthur Korn himself are among those included. There are numerous photographs of the Dessau Bauhaus, including many interesting interiors, and several of the buildings built for the Weissenhofsiedlung in Stuttgart. There is also a section on the use of glass in the decorative arts.

Korn was himself a key figure in the modern movement in Germany. As an architect in the 1910s and 1920s, he had been an associate of Erich Mendelsohn, Walter Gropius and Ernst May, before being forced to flea Germany in 1938. Once settled in England he became a leading member of of the MARS Group (Modern Architectural Research Group) - chairing their plan for the regeneration of London in 1942. He went on to teach at the Architectural Association in London for twenty years.

Book condition: Very good overall with signs of use consistent with age. There is minor yellowing to the page edges but the photographic plates remain crisp and stunning. There are no previous inscriptions, although for reasons unknown a previous owner has glued a small rectangle of brown paper (approx. 2cm x 3cm) to the title page beneath the title, next to the phrase ‘187 abbildungen’

The pulls are in excellent used condition with a wonderful patina created by decades of use, but no significant defects or damages. They will look fabulous put to re-use in the right setting.

The pulls are made of nickel plated brass and measure approximately 650 mm in length.

The final image is a scan from a catalogue published by the Velbert firm OGRO in 1936, taken from the website referenced below.

It was originally designed for the Savoy Hotel, Helsinki in 1937.

name: Richard Riemerschmid: Vom Jugendstil zum Werkbund
description:
Richard Riemerschmid: Vom Jugendstil zum Werkbund
Werke und Dokumente

Prestel-Verlag, Munchen, 1982

Softcover

Text in German

546 pages with a great many illustrations of works in black and white and colour.

Approximately 21 cm x 23.5

A fabulous and extremely scarce monograph on this hugely influential designer, whose elegant and functional forms forged a bridge between the Arts and Crafts period and the Modern Movement. Published to accompany an important retrospective exhibition held in Munich in 1982, it illustrates Riemerschmid's career in very great detail. There are separate sections covering his painting and graphic design (including typography), interior design and furniture, small furnishings (clocks, mirrors and other objects), lighting, metalware, ceramics, textile design and carpets and architecture. 

In all, a fascinating and invaluable resource for collectors and dealers that documents a great number of pieces in all media. The interior design and furniture section alone runs for over 160 pages. Each item featured is accompanied by detailed notes, including comments about variations of designs and bibliographic references.

Condition: The book is in excellent used condition. Internally it is extremely crisp, clean and bright with minimal signs of use. There's a little wear to the corners of the card wraps.

name: German Art Nouveau pot in the manner of Richard Riemerschmid, Merkelbach, Grenzhausen, 1904/5
description:
A rare German Art Nouveau lidded pot strongly in the manner of Richard Riemerschmid, Merkelbach, Grenzhausen, 1904/5

Circular and waved decoration in blue against a grey stoneware background with a hinged fixed lid and distinctive metal thumb rest. An extremely striking design, evocative of the period.

This design, strongly attributed to an important designer, is a fantastic expression of Jugendstil. The German manifestation of Art Nouveau was inspired not only by Art Nouveau as it was being expressed in France and Belgium, but also by the reforming ideals of John Ruskin and William Morris. Munich-based Riemerschmid exemplified this influence as much as any of his peers and his elegant and standardised decoration and forms went on exert considerable influence on the Modern Movement and the Bauhaus.

Size: About 10 cms in height and 14 cms in diameter.

Condition: Excellent, with some staining to the inside but no significant damages or signs of restoration.

Literature: See Richard Riemerschmid, From Art Nouveau to the Werkbund, Prestel, 1982, page 328 for illustrations of several very similar mustard pot designs.

name: Herbert Bayer 'Bauhaus 50 Jahre' Exhibition Poster, Stuttgart 1968
description:
Herbert Bayer Bauhaus 50 Years

Exhibition Poster, Stuttgart 1968

Vintage screenprint

Dimensions: Approx 59 cm x 42 cm (23 inches x 16.6)

Condition: Unused and in mint condition. 

Literature / References:
Arthur A. Cohen, Herbert Bayer The Complete Works, MIT Press, Cambridge, Mass., USA, 1984, p312
Phillips International Auctioneers and Valuers, Design Trilogy Part 1: Materials and Processes of the Twentieth Century, London, 6th December 1999, Lots 81 and 82

Background
This iconic image was created by the former Bauhaus student and teacher Bayer for the landmark 1968 Bauhaus retrospective which was held in Stuttgart in 1968.

Herbert Bayer had attended the Weimar Bauhaus as a pupil from 1921 to 1923, at the time the economic crisis in post-WW1 Weimar was developing and reaching its dramatic peak. He initially took Johannes Itten's revolutionary Preliminary Course on colour and form, then moved on to study mural painting with Wassily Kandinsky and Oskar Schlemmer. It was at this time that he created the Universal alphabet; the lower-case only typography now synonymous with the Bauhaus and its powerful legacy. In 1923 he was also commissioned by the Thuringian State in Weimar to design the new high value banknotes. The impoverished Weimer Republic government was desperately producing emergency notes - increasingly dramatic denominations - in a desperate attempt to combat acute hyper-inflation.
 
Bayer returned to the Bauhaus in 1925 - by then located at Dessau - as teacher, to lead a new course in advertising and typography. He remained a tutor there until 1928, the same year Bauhaus founder Walter Gropius departed. He emigated to the U.S.A in 1938 and established himself as a renowned graphic designer in America.

name: Modernist bowl by the Bauhaus student Karl Raichle, ca. 1935
description:
Karl Raichle was a student at the Dessau Bauhaus while the metalwork department was being run by László Moholy-Nagy.

Owing to leftist activism in his youth, Raichle was twice forced to relocate during the rise of the National Socialists.

His pieces - usually executed in pewter, copper or brass - are signed Meersburg, the town on Lake Constance where he was able to set up in business after 1933. Here he enjoyed the artistic influence of his friend the abstract painter Julius Bissier.

For further reading see:

Dedo von Kerssenbrock-Krosigk (ed), The Modern Art of Metalwork (1889-1939), Bröhan State Museum of Art Nouveau, Art Deco and Functionalism, Berlin, 2001.

Christie's Amsterdam, The Bauhaus and the Bauhaus Designers, 26 October 1989.

Details: The bowl is executed in hand-hammered edelzinn and measures approximately 100 mm approx in diameter by 45 mm high.

Condition: Very good indeed with a minor knock to the base but no significant damages or signs of repair. A wonderful rare find.

name: Ruppelwerk money box, attributed to Marianne Brandt, c. 1932
description:
A small Ruppelwerk money box with the legend ‘For the holidays’, the design attributed to Marianne Brandt, 1929-32.

Brandt’s tenure at the company was short-lived, coming after a short stint working at Walter Gropius’s architectural office in Berlin.

She took over control of the firm’s metal product range and was charged with updating and reviving it, but ultimately found the firm’s inveterate conservatism stifling.

This wonderful, rare piece - I have never come across another - is in excellent condition with expected minor wear to the enamel but no significant damages.

name: Damien Hirst PHARMACY | Sotheby's 2004 | Rare Catalogue including two sheets of stickers
description:
Damien Hirst's Pharmacy

Sotheby's, London, 18th October 2004

232 pages


A copy of this much sought-after catalogue, designed by Damien Hirst himself.
 
All 166 lots are artworks, furniture, equipment and fittings from Damien Hirst's famous Pharmacy Bar in Notting Hill. All are illustrated in full colour.

Many of the artworks - which include the artist's famous butterfly and dots series - are lavishly illustrated on gatefold pages (see photos). 

The lots are accompanied by detailed descriptions, but there are also several lengthy articles commenting on the artist, his art and the bar itself, making this an extremely informative and valuable - as well as beautiful - reference. damien hurst

The move to auction the contents of the ultimately ill-fated venture was viewed by many as a surprising and risky venture on Hirst's part with the potential to devalue his stock among serious art collectors. But the sale made  £11.1 million and helped Hirst re-affirm his status as one of the most conspicuously successful artists working today.

The condition is excellent with only the most minor signs of age on the cover. The catalogue comes complete with the original two pages of stickers, which are in very good condition. Also included is a printout detailing the actual prices realised at the sale.

A rare and highly collectable item - invaluable for all serious collectors. Don't miss out.

For more information on Pharmacy visit the Tate's interactive exhibit at http://www.tate.org.uk/pharmacy/default.htm 
 
© Text and scans copyright room_606. All rights reserved.

name: A modernist multi-functional table accessory by Wilhelm Wagenfeld associate Kurt Radtke for WMF
description:
Comprising two pieces of moulded blue-green glass, this striking mid-century modern item can be used as a candle-holder or bud vase for a table setting.

This iconic piece was created by Radtke while working alongside the Bauhaus designer Wilhelm Wagenfeld.

It is a perfect expression of WMF's contribution to the functionalist Bauhaus tradition as an inexpensive, effortlessly functional and essentially democratic household object. 

In very good used condition with signs of age and use but no significant damages. Please see the pictures. 

Approx. height 55 mm.

name: Die Form: Zeitschrift für gestaltende Arbeit  July 1930 ( The Kiefhoek by J.J.P. Oud )
description:
An issue of the rare German Bauhaus-era design periodical Die Form: Zeitschrift für gestaltende Arbeit, a fortnightly journal on progressive design.

Year 5 - Issue 14 - June 1930

The periodical was published in Berlin by Verlag Hermann Reckendorf for the Deutscher Werkbund (German Work Federation).

The Deutscher Werkbund, widely known as the DWB, was a collaboration of leading artists and designers intent on reflecting the florid excesses of Art Nouveau and Jugendstil in favour of promoting the marriage of artistic endeavour with mass production.

Their famous Cologne Exhibition of 1914 included Walter Gropius' steel and glass model factory, Bruno Taut's Glass Pavilion and Henry Van Der Velde's Werkbund Theatre. Peter Behrens, Bruno Paul, Richard Riemerschmid, Josef Maria Olbrich and Wiener Werkstatte founder Josef Hoffmann were all among its members.

The group went on to exert enormous influence in the progress of modernist design and functionalism, particularly in the formation of the Bauhaus.

This issue from July 1930 is replete with photographs of modernist architecture, furniture and interiors and features a fabulous 11-page illustrated article on the nascent Kiefhoek housing estate, designed by J.J.P. Oud in Rotterdam. 

The project - built between 1928-30 by a key figure of De Stijl - gave rise to a complete modernist neighbourhood, is a true highlight of the Modern Movement and was declared a national Dutch monument in the 1990s.

Other topics covered include news of a new housing development underway in Cologne and the Lichtbild art exhibition in Munich, held that year.

Condition: It is very good indeed with only minor signs of ageing and use. The pages are clean and bright with no foxing. There is a neat ink inscription and institution stamp on the title page and a faint inscription in pencil on the back cover.

name: Three nudes by František Drtikol, 1928-29
description:
Here are three classic nudes by František Drtikol, taken in 1928 and 1929.

Reminiscent of Cubism, to me they encapsulate the eclecticism of Czech avant-garde of the period. 

Partly by virtue of its location in the heart of Europe, Czechoslovakia benefited from the free flow of progressive ideas – and absorbed Cubism, Dada, and polemics from Bauhaus, Dutch De Stijl and Russian Constructivist circles - to forge a distinctive contribution to the modernist avant-garde.

The prints I’m offering are from the folio ‘Akt V Ceske Fotografii’ (the Nude in Czech Photography), published by Orbis, Prague in 1967.

Size: 125 x 175 mm approx.

Unframed

Condition: Very good +. Each image has a white border on the bottom edge, as originally printed.

name: Kaiser Idell model 6739 desk lamp by Christian Dell, 1930s
description:
A Model 6739 desk lamp designed by Christian Dell for the Kaiser Company, Neheim-Hüsten, Germany 

The lamp is constructed from black lacquered steel and has a flexible 'swan neck' that allows the height and angle to be adjusted for specific tasks. The clamp fixture is complete, retainaing its original heart-shaped screw and white switch.

As the master in charge of the metalwork department at the Staatliches Bauhaus in Weimar, Christian Dell (1893-1974) worked in close collaboration with other modernist luminaries such as Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, Marianne Brandt, Hin Bredendieck and Hans Przyrembel. Although also a silversmith and jeweller he is now best known as functionalist innovator and a key figure in the development of industrial lighting. His significance in the story of twentieth century design is becoming increasingly recognised by museums worldwide.


Materials: Lacquered steel. 

Size: About 55cm in height. The diameter of the shade is approximately 21 cm. 

References: See Idee Christian Dell, Peter M. Klein & Klaus Struve, Museum fur Licht und Beleuchtung, 1995.

Condition: The lamp is in very good original condition with expected surface signs of age and use but no damages. There is some general ageing in the form of some dulling to the lacquer, but no significant damages such as splits, cracks, corrosion or deep scratches. I could find no signs of restoration to the metal. The lamp has vintage - though apparently not original - continental European wiring and works but must be renewed by a qualified electrician. Please see my important note about vintage electrical items below.

name: A rare vintage Braun AB 20 exact quartz alarm clock designed by Dieter Rams and D. Lubs in 1975
description:
Braun model number 4963
Measuring approximately 86 mm x 62 x 40

You could argue that this clock is a piece of twentieth century design history - it was the first of Braun's analogue bedside alarm clock range.
It was co-designed by Dieter Rams and Dietrich Lubs in 1975 and being the earliest in the series, is a collectors' piece and correspondingly hard-to-find.
The classic Braun analogue clock features - the matte black casing, pared down dial and coloured hands (wide white hands for hours and minutes, narrow yellow for sweeping seconds hand and inconspicuous black hand with contrasting coloured point for the alarm setting) - are already present. It has a rocker switch next to the dial for the alarm. 
The clock is in excellent vintage used condition - it's fully working with only light surface handling marks and no damages. It's an extremely nice piece.


Reference
See Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, page 226 and 472 for more information.

name: Modernist industrial Midgard task lamp designed by Curt Fischer
description:
A rare modernist Midgard task lamp designed by Curt Fischer for Industriewerke Auma, Ronneberger & Fischer, Auma, Thüringen, Germany

Originally designed in the early 1920s, this example must date from the 1940s

Enamelled and chrome-plated steel

Impressed signature and manufacturer’s mark to pivoting stem and on the cylindrical joint fixing the shade to the.

Approximate Measurements: Height about 680 mm, diameter of shade about 170 mm

 

 

Midgard’s first functionalist task lights were contemporaneous with the emergence of the Bauhaus and proved a significant inspiration on its inhabitants – examples are documented to have been in use throughout the Weimar Bauhaus and later even inside Walter Gropius’s own study at his Master’s House adjacent to the school at Dessau.

Indeed, it is referenced in the Bauhaus-Archiv Museum exhibition catalogue Die Metallwerkstatt am Bauhaus (The Bauhaus Metal Workshop), where author Klaus Weber writes:

‘The Midgard lamp has the advantage of being extremely practical as it can be adjusted in several different ways. In the 1920s the Bauhaus used it in their workshops as they considered it useful and convenient lighting. Marianne Brandt, comparing Curt Fischer's light with the general Bauhaus model, said: "even if our lights are adjustable, they are not as elegant and we envied the creator of the Midgard lamp."’

Condition

Very good indeed. As you would expect from a vintage item, it has taken some minor knocks over the years and their are expected minor surface traces of use consistent with age, but no significant damages such as cracks or major dents to the metal or corrosion. I believe the enamelling is original. The lamp has been rewired at some point by a previous owner with what appears to be modern continental European wiring and it works. However the wiring is not mine so I cannot absolutely guarantee its safe use or continuing functionality. In common with all vintage electrical items, I have to state that it must be examined by a qualified electrician before use. Please see my important note concerning the sale of vintage electrical items below. 



A fabulous find.



References

Bauhaus-Archiv Museum für Gestaltung, Die Metallwerkstatt am Bauhaus, Berlin, 1992, p. 101, ill. 129.

For illustrations of similar Fischer / Midgard lamps see:

Quittenbaum Auction House, München, Auction 66, Lot 194, estimate 700 EUR.

Wright Auction House Chicago, Mass Modern, Lot 319, 16 September 2006, Estimate: $1,000–1,500

name: German Art Nouveau period water jug by F. & R. Fischer, c. 1910
description:
This is a significant piece, dating from the end of the Art Nouveau period. A noted precursor of modernism, this design is held in the collection of the Bröhan Museum of Art Nouveau, Art Deco and Functionalism, in Berlin and illustrated and described in the museum's catalogue, Modern Art of Metalwork, on page 155. Another example of this jug is on display at the Bauhaus Archive in Berlin.

It also appeared in the Deutsches Warenbuch of 1915 and bears close comparison to contemporary Deutscher Werkbund pieces by Peter Behrens, Bruno Paul, Josef Maria Olbrich and Richard Riemerschmid and others. In fact, in some volumes the design is firmly attributed to Riemerschmid, although this is not substantiated by Brohan, probably the most authoritative source.

The Deutscher Werkbund (DWB) was a group founded by Peter Behrens and Josef Hoffmann and involving Walter Gropius among others to promote the marriage of artistic endeavour with mass production. They went on to exert enormous influence in the progess of modernist design and functionalism, particularly in the formation of the Bauhaus.

F. & R. Fischer operated from a factory in Göppingen, southern Germany. Little is known about precisely which designers contributed designs for them, but their consciously functional and forward-looking workbetrays the influence of Art Nouveau, the Wiener Werkstatte and Jan Eisenloeffel among others.

Description: The jug is of spherical form with cup-shaped lid and curving thumb-rest and raffia covered handle. The jug is executed in hand hammered nickel plated brass. It has interior pewter plating and bears the Fischer factory mark (two fish in an oval) the underside.
 
Size: It stands at about 6 inches in height.
 
Condition: Very good original condition, with only minor surface signs of age and use. There are no significant damages - just a couple of minor bumps to the metal. The fragile raffia handle is fragile but in good condition.

name: A hyperinflation bank note designed inside the Bauhaus by Herbert Bayer, 1923
description:
Herbert Bayer attended the Weimar Bauhaus as a pupil from 1921 to 1923, at the time the economic crisis in post-WW1 Weimar was developing and reaching its dramatic peak.

He initially took Johannes Itten's revolutionary Preliminary Course on colour and form, then moved on to study mural painting with Wassily Kandinsky and Oskar Schlemmer.

It was at this time that he created the Universal alphabet; the lower-case only typography now synonymous with the Bauhaus and its powerful legacy.

In 1923 he was also commissioned by the Thüringian State in Weimar to design the new high value banknotes. The impoverished Weimer Republic government was desperately producing emergency money - increasingly high single note denominations - in an attempt to combat acute hyper-inflation.

Bayer returned to the Bauhaus in 1925 - now located at Dessau - as teacher, to lead a new course in advertising and typography. He remained a tutor there until 1928, the same year Bauhaus founder Walter Gropius departed.

LITERATURE An illustration of the banknote can be found in the catalogue for the famous 50 Years of the Bauhaus exhibition, which was held at the Royal Academy in London in 1968, on page 118.

CONDITION The note is in good to very good circulated condition with some wear and marking consistent with age and use but no damages or repairs. The note measures approx. 9.1 cm x 14.4 cm.

Text and photos Copyright © Matthew Grice 2013

name: Rare single person coffee pot by Wilhelm Wagenfeld for WMF, ca. 1957
description:
The avant-garde really does meet the every day in this wonderful piece by a celebrated Bauhaus designer.

It was created by Wagenfeld for WMF in the mid-1950s for a startlingly modernist range intended for use in hotels. 

Executed in 'German silver' or 'alpacca' (the NS 22 on the underside stands for Neu silber with 22g of silver content) and measuring approx 11.6 cms in height. The capacity is 0.28 litres. 

The pot is signed on the underside with the following: WMF NS 22 0,28L

Condition: In excellent used condition with some minor signs of wear. There is expected surface marking - light scratching - fully consistent with age and use but no damages or signs of repair.

Reference: See Auktionhaus Siebers Stuttgart, Wilhelm Wagenfeld: The Dr Carlo Burschel Collection, p. 82 for illustrations.

name: An enameled metal and bakelite 'Bauhaus Telephone' by Fuld & Co., Germany, c.1935
A floral pattern ceramic tile by William De Morgan, c.1885
description: ***This item is currently for sale on another website. Please click here for more information. This is a Bedford Park Anemone tile, with quartered design of yellow flowers and green foliage with turquoise highlights. name: A rare gold-plated Braun TFG 1 Permanent Table Lighter by Reinhold Weiss, 1965
description:
Here's a supremely rare Braun piece - a gold-plated TFG 1.

Dating from 1965, the TFG 1 was the company’s first lighter and quickly attracted the alternative moniker 'the toaster', for visually obvious reasons. The sliding switch mechanism was a design innovation at the time.

It was created by Reinhold Weiss, then working under the design directorship of Dieter Rams. Weiss was the designer of several landmark Braun pieces of this period, including the HL 1 desk fan and HUV 1 sun lamp, both of which are represented in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA), New York.

This lighter has a gold-plated case, making it a real luxuriant rarity. They are usually found in either polished chrome metal or in chrome with a panel of black faux-leather.

The piece is marked Braun permanent, Made in West Germany on the underside.  It measures approximately 105mm long by 32mm wide and 75 mm high and takes a type of fuel - gas - that's still very commonly available today.

It’s in extremely good vintage cosmetic condition.  It has only minor surface signs of use consistent with decades of careful use – there are no deep scratches, cracks or signs of repair. 

The mechanism sparks and works but but is inconsistent. Because vintage items can go wrong at any time, it is being sold here as a display item only.

***In the final picture the TFG 1 is pictured with a silver-plated T2 lighter by Dieter Rams. Please note that the T2 is not included in this sale but available in a separate listing.***

In all, a wonderful, museum quality example of 1960s Braun design. This model was only produced for two years and is correspondingly hard to find.

References
See Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, p 257 and 476 for an illustration and more information.


© Text and photographs copyright room_606 (2013).

name: EAMES OFFICE | Ticket for Griffith Park miniature railway, Los Angeles, 1957
description:
In 1957 the Eames Office was invited to completely re-design a miniature railway at the Los Angeles amusement park Griffith Park.

This is a rare surviving ticket from the small-scale and slightly homespun project, which the Eameses undertook despite having already earned an international reputation by this stage of their careers.

For inspiration they drew upon a toy train set they had in their own collection and late nineteenth century carnival memorabilia.

For more information see Pat Kirkham, Charles and Ray Eames: Designers of the twentieth century, MIT Press, 1998, pp 130-131.

Size: 2.5 inches (h) x 1.75 (w)

Paper

Rare

name: Kandem desk lamp
description:
A modernist desk lamp, manufactured by Kandem (Korting und Mathieson), Leipzig, Germany, in the late 1930s

 **Please scroll down for multiple pictures 
 
Background:
Walter Gropius intended the Bauhaus at Dessau to be a factory of ideas and innovation that attracted the co-operation of industry. He hoped that the design prototypes his masters and students produced would be taken up by the leading companies of the day and - in close collaboration with the School - developed for industrial production.
This ambition was successful only in a few cases, but this lamp is an example of one such collaboration. The alliance between the Bauhaus and the Leipzig-based firm Korting und Mathieson began in the late 1920s and persisted into the 1930s.
By co-operating with the Bauhaus, Kandem acquired creative partnerships with several of its key figures, including Marianne Brandt, Hin Bredendieck and Laszlo Moholy-Nagy.
 
Details:
The lamp clearly exhibits the company's Bauhaus functionalist ethos. 

Executed in a very dark green lacquered metal, the lamp is very flexible and manoeuvrable. The curved arm is set into the base with a ball socket and the joint that links the arm to the shade pivots up and down. 

The lamp retains its original switch and is signed K & M for Korting and Mathieson on the underside of the base. The shade is enamelled white on the inside. 
It stands at approximately 480 mm in height, while the diameter of the shade is about 180 mm.
 
Bibliographic references:
See Bauhausleuchten? Kandemlicht! (Bauhaus Lighting? Kandem light!: The Collaboration of the Bauhaus with the Leipzig Company Kandem), Justus A. Binroth et al., Arnoldsche Art Publishers, Stuttgart, pp 144/5. 
 
Condition:
The lamp is in excellent used condition with just very minor general surface wear consistent with age. There are no significant damages such as dents or scratches. The lamp retains vintage (though apprently not original) European wiring and works. In common with all vintage electrical items it must be safety checked by a qualified electrician before use. Please see the important note on this below.


© Text and photographs by room_606 (2013). All rights reserved.

name: Die Form: Monatsschrift für gestaltende Arbeit | Heft 6 1928
description:
An issue of the rare German Bauhaus-era design periodical Die Form, a monthly journal on progressive design.

Year 3 - Issue 6 - June 1928

The periodical was published in Berlin by Verlag Hermann Reckendorf for the Deutscher Werkbund (German Work Federation). 

The Deutscher Werkbund, widely known as the DWB, was a collaboration of leading artists and designers intent on reflecting the florid excesses of Art Nouveau and Jugendstil in favour of promoting the marriage of artistic endeavour with mass production. 

Their famous Cologne Exhibition of 1914 included Walter Gropius' steel and glass model factory, Bruno Taut's Glass Pavilion and Henry Van Der Velde's Werkbund Theatre. Peter Behrens, Bruno Paul, Richard Riemerschmid, Josef Maria Olbrich and Wiener Werkstatte founder Josef Hoffmann were all among its members. 

The group went on to exert enormous influence in the progress of modernist design and functionalism, particularly in the formation of the Bauhaus. 

This issue from June 1928 is replete with photographs of modernist architecture, furniture and interiors and features articles by the architect Wilhelm Lotz and Walter Riezler among others. The contents are listed as follows:

Furnishings and furniture types (featuring multiple illustrations of chair designs by Ludwig Mies Van Der Rohe and Ferdinand Kramer, among others) | A Design for a Stadium | A contribution to the reform of cemeteries | The anniversary of the Wiener Werkstätte

Condition: It is generally very good with some expected signs of ageing and use. The pages are clean and bright with no foxing. The front cover has only minor fading and wear to the extremities and displays brilliantly. The binding is fragile with some stress on the staples at the title page, but elsewhere it is holding together very well so I would describe it as very good overall. There are no inscriptions except for some faint pencil marks on the back cover.

description:

Jihoslovanská Knihovna (The South Slavic Library) 

Published by L. Mazác, Prague, Czechoslovakia, 1938

A complete set of all 10 volumes

9 Softcover in pictorial wraps, 1 Hardcover in pictorial DJ

Size appox. 21.5 x 14 cm

All bookjackets in the series designed by the Devetsil artist / designer Frantisek Muzika


The titles:

1. Vladimir Levstik, Cin

2. Dinko Simunovic, Rodina Vincicu

3. Vladimir Nazor, Povidky z detství

4. Tone Seliskar, Na úskali

5. Petar S.Petrovic, Vesnice spí

6. Miroslav Krleza, Návrat Filipa Latinovicze

7. Ivo Andric, Mara milostnice

8. Veljko Petrovic, Zapálené obilí

9. Dragisa Vasic, Bubenic Resimic

10. Jus Kozak, Bilý modrín 



Wonderful groundbreaking photomontage book design by one of the key figures of the Czech avant-garde of the 1930s.

Devetsil was at the centre of the Czech art scene of the period; besides Muzika its members included Karel Tiege, Jaroslav Seifert, Adolf Hoffmeister, Vitezslav Nezval, Konstantin Biebl, Otakar Mrkvicka, Jindrich Styrsky and Toyen.

It was responsible for publishing the several important theorizing periodicals and almanacs – among them ReD (Revue Devětsilu), Devětsil and Život.

References:
For illustrations of Muzika book-jackets from the Jihoslovanská Knihovna series, see:  Toman, J. The Modern Czech Book. Photo/Montage in Print. Prague 2009, page 200.

Condition:

The overall condition is very good. This is a very fragile publication and I would rate this extremely rare set as an excellent survival. The bindings are fragile throughout and the roughly cut page edges are a little dusty. Number 5, Vesnice spí, is the hardcover edition and in excellent condition. The all important covers are very good, though a little yellowed and slightly worn at the edges and very fragile at the spine in places they display beautifully. Some volumes have mylar covers. A stunning collection.


 
© Text and photographs copyright room_606 (2012). All rights reserved.

name: MAGIC MOTORWAYS Norman Bel Geddes (1940)
description:
MAGIC MOTORWAYS Norman Bel Geddes

Published by Random House, New York in 1940.

International First Edition and stated first printing

Hardback with dark brown/maroon lettering on cream boards.

Size: Approx 21 cm x 27 cm



It's no exaggeration to describe Norman Bel Geddes as one of the most important designers of the Art Deco period. His unrepentantly visionary approach to industrial design is documented in this book, in which the designer himself lays out in words, plans photographs and drawings his startling futuristic manifesto for modernising transport.
 
This stylish book records and expands on Geddes's celebrated exhibit at the 1939 Worlds Fair. Futurama: Metropolis of Tomorrow  mesmerised over five million (!) visitors with its creator's startlingly forward-looking plan for a utopian automobile-based national traffic system, complete with teardrop-shaped cars, cities of Art Deco glass and steel skyscrapers and open parklands intersected by seven-lane highways.
 
The influence Futurama left on visitors and commentators at the time was monumental and it earned General Motors, who had commissioned the exhibit, lasting kudos. Decades later the project received a reverential nod from Matt Groening, in the title of his undeservedly shortlived Sci-fi follow-up to The Simpsons.
 
Condition: International FIRST EDITION and stated First Printing. Hardback in with dark brown/maroon lettering on cream boards. Condition: Very good indeed with only minor signs of age and use. No DJ. There is a little bumping to the covers and some foxing to the front and rear end papers only. Both externally and internally it is very clean and bright and the binding is tight. The black and white photographs are vibrant. Extremely rare and much sought-after in any condition. A seminal Machine Age book.

name: Modernist napkin holder by Marianne Brandt for Ruppelwerk, c.1930
description:
Red enamelled metal in triangular form, with geometric sides, standing on two curved feet.
 
Marked 'RUPPEL geschuzt' and with the firm's solid star motif to the underside

Condition: 
In very good used condition with some expected wear to the metal in places but no significant damages. There are no scratches, dents or signs of restoration. In my experience, this is an uncommon design.


Size: 
Approximately 13 cms high and 21 cm wide.

Background:
As a member of the metalwork department at the Staatliches Bauhaus in Weimar, Marianne Brandt  (1893-1983) worked in close collaboration with other modernist luminaries such as Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, Christian Dell, Hin Bredendieck and Hans Przyrembel. 

She was appointed assistant director of the workshop by Walter Gropius when the Bauhaus moved to Dessau in 1928. 
Although a painter and sculptor as well as a metalwork designer, she is probably best known for the pioneering functionalist metalwork designs she produced at the Bauhaus and for the lighting manufacturer Kandem (Korting & Mathiesen) and the Metallwarenfabrik (metalware factory) Ruppelwerk, Gotha, of which this is an iconic example. 
Her position as a prominent figure in the history of twentieth century design is well established.

References: 
See Sotheby's, Bauhaus and other important 20th century Avant-garde Design, 1 November 1996, Lot 76. Estimate £400-600.
Also Die Metallwerkstatt am Bauhaus (The Bauhaus Metal Workshop), Bauhaus Archiv, Berlin, 1992, Plate 116. 


Text and photographs © Room 606 (2012). All rights reserved.

name: A Braun DN 50 Visotronic digital alarm clock, 1979
description:
A wonderful Braun piece – and one of my personal favourites. It looks like the ultimate 70s design item, but somehow it's also hard to believe that it is over 30 years old.

The stylish L-shaped design is matched by a range of functions that includes an automatically dimming LED display and touch sensitive snooze bar.

This was conceived by Littmann while he was working under the Design Directorship of Dieter Rams.

It’s in excellent vintage used condition. The display is bright, the clock keeps excellent time and the alarm and snooze functions work. It has only very minor surface signs of use consistent with decades of careful use – there are no deep scratches, cracks or signs of repair. 

Please note that the item’s functionality has been tested on the European mains electricity supply – others please check with an electrician local to you to confirm functionality. The label states that the clock uses 220 V ~ /50 Hz. All vintage electrical items should be safety checked before use. Needless to say, being a vintage item, its longevity as an accurate or functioning timepiece can't be guaranteed.


References

An example is held in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) in New York. For more information see: http://www.moma.org/collection/object.php?object_id=2803. 

Also see Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, pp 227 for an illustration and more information.
