name: A Kaiser Idell Model 6723 wall lamp designed in the mid 1930s by the Bauhaus teacher Christian Dell
description:
As the master in charge of the metalwork department at the Staatliches Bauhaus in Weimar, Christian Dell (1893-1974) worked in close collaboration with other modernist luminaries such as Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, Marianne Brandt, Hin Bredendieck and Hans Przyrembel. Although also a silversmith and jeweller he is now best known as functionalist innovator and a key figure in the development of industrial lighting. His significance in the story of twentieth century design is becoming increasingly recognised by museums worldwide.

Executed in black lacquered steel. Stamped 'Kaiser Idell Original' to the rear of the shade.

The lamp is in excellent original condition with only expected ageing and minor wear to the surface of the lacquer, but no dents, deep scratches or other significant damages to the metal. It retains its original bakelite switch. 

At some point it has been rewired with Continental European wiring and currently works, but MUST be checked by an electrician before use.

A great piece of authentic, and dramatic, Bauhaus design for your home. 

© Description and photographs © copyright room_606, 2012. All rights reserved.

name: The Art-Revival in Austria
description:
The Art-Revival in Austria
The Studio Special Summer Number, 1906 

London, The Studio, 1906

Hardcover in maroon cloth boards with gilt titling to the spine

Profusely illustrated in color and black & white, with 91 plates, several mounted.

The book covers architecture, painting, furniture, decorative arts and sculpture during one of the most creative periods in Austrian history.  In particular, it is a fantastic contemporary reference on the early years of the Wiener Werkstätte with works by Josef Hoffmann, Gustav Klimt, Josef Urban, Kolo Moser, Josef Olbrich, Otto Prutscher, Ferdinand Andri, Emil Orlik, Leopold Bauer, Hans Ofner, Jan Kotera, Robery Oerley, Czescka, Heinrich Lefler, Otto Wagner, Michael Powolny, Jutta Sika and Berthold Loffler illustrated among others. 
koloman moser
The Studio was undoubtedly the most influential fine, decorative and applied art periodical of its age. It was edited by Charles Holme.

Condition: Ex-library in very good indeed condition. The library markings are more discreet than you usually find; confined to a neat label on the front, are label on the inside cover and a stamp and index number on the title page. The covers are very good, if a little worn around the edges. Internally the book is very clean and bright, aside from foxing and marking to the front and rear endpapers only. This is an excellent survival.

name: Ulm door handle, Max Bill and Ernst Moeckl, 1955
description:
You may have already noticed, but I have a thing about modernist door handles.

Minor details like door handles were important to Modern Movement architects (as exponents of the Gesamtkunstwerk ideal) and I think that it is fair to say that there are several key designs from the period, associated with key buildings or building projects, that have become iconic.

The handle Ferdinand Kramer created for Ernst May’s ‘New Frankfurt’ social housing project of the mid-1920s is one, and I would argue that the above pictured example is another.

This handle was originally designed by Max Bill and Ernst Moeckl in 1955 for the Hochschule für Gestaltung (HfG Ulm), while the former was Director and the latter, a student.

It resists the geometry of Kramer’s - and the classic handle Gropius and Meyer created for the Bauhaus - adopting a more elegant form that refers more succinctly its functional interaction with the hand.

Incidentally, Moeckl and Bill also worked together on this notable kitchen clock for Junghans, an example of which is held in the permanent collection of the Victoria and Albert Museum in London.

The door handle is in excellent condition with only minor signs of use.

name: Rare early Braun compact quartz alarm clock, designed by Dietrich Lubs in 1982
description:
Braun model number 4829

Measuring approximately 80 mm w x 70 h x 40 d

A rare early Braun compact quartz clock, designed by Lubs in 1982 while working under the design directorship of Dieter Rams.

With matte black casing, pared down dial and coloured hands (wide white hands for hours and minutes, narrow yellow for sweeping seconds hand and inconspicuous black hand with contrasting coloured point for the alarm setting). 

Having the protective fold-down front cover - with world time zones printed on the inside - makes this a very rare piece.

With all elements designed to prioritise ease-of-use for the user, it's a fabulous example of Braun's timeless Bauhaus-tradition design.

The clock is in excellent vintage used condition - it's fully working with only very light surface handling marks and no damages. 


Reference
See Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, pp 473 for more information.  



© Text and photographs copyright room_606 2013. All rights reserved.

name: Die Wohnung poster stamp, 1927
description:
A rare vintage poster stamp for the landmark modernist architecture exhibition Die Wohnung, 1927

Approx 92 mm by 31 mm

Excellent conditon. The design on the front of the stamp is very clean and bright with no marks. There a few marks along one of the edges on the gummed rear, although in my opinion the stamp does not appear to have been used.



Held in 1927, Die Wohnung (or The Dwelling) was a major Deutscher Werkbund exhibition that became a key moment in the emergence of the International Style in architecture.

Bauhaus founder Walter Gropius, Le Corbusier, Peter Behrens, Bruno Taut, Mart Stam and J.J.P Oud were all among the architects invited by project director Ludwig Mies Van Der Rohe to create buildings for an entire estate of progressive buildings specially created in the Weissenhof suburb of Stuttgart.  

Despite damage during WW2 and subsequent unsympathetic urban regeneration many of the buildings of the  Weissenhofsiedlung (Weissenhof Estate) have been restored and two have been shortlisted for UNESCO heritage status reflecting the site's international architectural significance.

The Deutscher Werkbund (DWB) was a group founded by Peter Behrens and Josef Hoffmann among others to promote the marriage of artistic endeavour with mass production. They went on to exert enormous influence in the progess of modernist design and functionalism, particularly in the formation of the Bauhaus.

For more information on the Weißenhofsiedlung, visit the excellent official website at weissenhofsiedlung.de.

name: A modernist bud vase by the Bauhaus trained designer Karl Raichle, c. 1935
description:
Karl Raichle was a student at the Dessau Bauhaus while the metalwork department was being run by László Moholy-Nagy.

Owing to leftist activism in his youth, Raichle was twice forced to relocate during the rise of the National Socialists.

His pieces - invariably executed in pewter, copper or brass - are uysually signed Meersburg, the town on Lake Constance where he was able to set up in business after 1933. Here he enjoyed the artistic influence of his friend the abstract painter Julius Bissier.

For further reading see:

Dedo von Kerssenbrock-Krosigk (ed), The Modern Art of Metalwork (1889-1939), Bröhan State Museum of Art Nouveau, Art Deco and Functionalism, Berlin, 2001.

Christie's Amsterdam, The Bauhaus and the Bauhaus Designers, 26 October 1989.

Details and condition: Executed in hand-hammered edelzinn. Stands at approx 270 mm in height while the diameter of the base is about 61 mm. The condition is very good indeed with some minor expected patination to the metal but no significant damages. A wonderful rare find.

name: Vintage Braun ET 22 Control Calculator by Dieter Rams and Dietrich Lubs, 1976
description:
Braun model number 4955
Plastic 
Size approx 145 (l) x 80 (w) x 25 (d) mm

This early Braun pocket calculater was designed by Rams and Lubs in 1976. If the design looks familiar it it's because the Control range was given a reverential nod by Apple when it came to designing the iPhone calculator in 2007. 
It’s in very good vintage used condition and comes complete with its protective hard plastic outer sleeve. It works. It has some expected light wear. There are light surface handling marks to the plastic but no significant damages. 


Reference
See Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, pages 242 and 475 for an illustration and more information.  



© Text and photographs by room_606 (2013). All rights reserved.

name: DIE FORM OHNE ORNAMENT
description:
DIE FORM OHNE ORNAMENT

Bucher Der Form Volume 1

Deutscher Werkbund, 1925

Hardback

102 pages, profusely illustrated with black and white photographic plates

*Please scroll down for more pictures


An extremely important moment in the history of the modern movement, Die Form ohne Ornament (Form without ornament) was published by the Deutscher Werkbund (DWB) in 1924 and was the first in their famous and groundbreaking series titled Bucher Der Form (Books on Form).

The DWB was a colloboration of designers united by the rejection of Art Nouveau/Jugendstil in favour of purer forms reflecting mass production. Luminaries Bruno Paul, Peter Behrens, Richard Riemerschmidt, Josef Maria Olbrich and Wiener Werkstätte founder Josef Hoffmann  were all among its founder members.

The book, which is full of black and white photographic plates, was remarkable at the time of publication in its exclusive celebration of artistic endeavour in the decorative arts inspired by industrial production. 

It features several important works from the Wiener Werkstatte and the early Weimar period of the Bauhaus.

Size: Approximately 19cm x 26cm

Condition: Very good indeed. Aside from a little expected yellowing on the end papers, internally it is very bright and clean. The board covers are sound. There are no inscriptions.

name: Original Braun KMM 1 Aromatic Coffee Grinder by Reinhold Weiss, 1964
description:
This fabulous Braun piece was Braun's first coffee grinder and its launch marked a significant moment of domestic modernisation that's reflected in the minimalism of the design. 

Its mains operated stone mill mechanism marked the end of the long-winded manual process of grinding the beans by hand.

Weiss was the designer of several truly landmark Braun products - including the TFG 1 table lighter, HLD 2 hair dryer and the HL 1 and HL 70 desk fans. The Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) in New York has no fewer than eleven of his creations in its permanent collection.

The grinder is mains operated and has a standard European 2-pin plug. Please note that the item’s functionality has been tested on the European mains electricity supply (220 V) – others please check with an electrician local to you to confirm functionality. The wiring is original. 

Please note that all vintage electrical items are sold here as decorative items only and must be fully safety checked by a qualified electrician before being plugged into the mains, if you decide you want to use them. Please see my important condition of sale note covering all types of vintage electrical items below. 

This example is in good but well-used condition - everything still works as it should but it has clearly seen many years of service. The plexiglass cover has become slightly clouded over time and there are light surface marks here and there. An excellent find!

Reference
Also see Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, pages 446 and 496 for an illustration and more information.

name: An ABK 31 - or Model No. 4781 - wall clock by Dietrich Lubs for BRAUN, 1985
description:
A fabulous example of Braun's influential Bauhaus tradition design, this piece differs from the more commonly seen ABK 20 in that it has a clear perspex cover for the dial. Created by Lubs while working under the design directorship of Dieter Rams, it reflects both designers’ practical minimalism.

The clock is fully factory marked both on the front of the dial and reverse. It measures approx. 20 cm in diameter and approx 3.75 cm in depth, it is in very good used condition and full working order. There are some minor signs of age and use, some light surface scratching to the clear perspex dial cover, but no significant damages or signs of repair. As with all vintage white plastic, the colour has yellowed somewhat over time.

Reference

See Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, pages 238 and 474 for an illustration and more information.

name: Almanach Kmene 1933 - 1934 | Marie Majerová | Slavoboj Tusar | Josef Čapek
description:
A copy of the Czech avant-garde cultural and literary almanac ‘Kmene’, published by the Club of Modern Publishers in Prague in 1933.

Edited by the writer Marie Majerová, with vibrant cover by the typeface designer Slavoboj Tusar.

Featuring a wonderful illustration by Josef Capek.

Softcover

196 pages

Size approx. 19.3 x 12.2 cm 

Condition: The overall condition is very good. Internally it is clean and there are no previous owner inscriptions. The binding is fragile though sound and the page edges are rough and in some case uncut. The all important wraps are very good, though a little worn at the edges and spine. Czech softcovers of this vintage are always fragile and I would rate this as an uncommonly good survival.

name: The Artists of the Darmstadt Colony | Behrens Olbrich Margold Albin Müller
description:
Die Kunstler der Mathildenhöhe
(The Artists of the Darmstadt Colony)

Ein Dokument Deutscher Kunst 1901-1976: Volume 4.

Eduard Roether Verlag
Darmstadt, 1976-7
 
Unpaginated but approximately 232 pages with a great many illustrations in colour and black and white.
 
Illustrated card wrappers.
 
Text in German
 

Darmstadt: Ein Dokument Deutscher Kunst was an important exhibition held at the Mathildenhohe, Darmstadt in October 1976 to January 1977. This is volume four of the exhaustive five book monograph to accompany the exhibition. Volume four is the most sought after because it provides comprehensive coverage of each of the designers of the Darmstadt school with a great many illustrations of their work. These include Peter Behrens, Hans Christiansen, Patriz Huber, Emanuel Josef Margold, Albin Müller and Joseph Maria Olbrich.
 
In its expression of the dynamic German response to Art Nouveau, the influence of the Darmstadt colony is too often overlooked or understated.

It directly influenced the Austrian avant garde and particularly the establishment of the Wiener Werkstatte and later, via the Deutscher Werkbund, the emergence of modernism.

An extremely valuable reference for students, enthusiasts, collectors and dealers in German Art Nouveau, featuring myriad
illustrations of work by the artists and designers of the Darmstadt Artists' Colony and fascinating documentary photographs of the settlement itself.
 
The books measures approximately 22 cm (8.75 inches) square.
 
Condition: In very good condition indeed with only minor signs age and use. Internally the pages are very clean and bright.

name: Original modernist door handles designed by Hans POELZIG, ca. 1935 [4 pairs available]
description:
These striking period door handles were specifically designed for the administrative offices of the giant I.G. Farben paint factory in Frankfurt.

The building, completed in 1931, was the work of the architect, painter and set designer Hans Poelzig.

One of the progenitors of the Modern Movement, Poelzig participated in the first major International Style project, the 1927 Die Wohnung expo.

The event saw the construction of an entire estate of modernist dwellings in the elevated Weissenhof suburb of Stuttgart.

Poelzig contributed a prototype single family house alongside Le Corbusier, Mies van der Rohe, Gropius and Behrens among others.

His imposing I.G. Farben building still stands and has become the centrepiece of the Goethe University campus in Frankfurt. Poelzig died in 1936, aged 67.

The nickel-plated brass door handles are offered without lock plates. They are in good to very good condition with signs of use and wear commensurate with age but no significant damages. They will look fabulous re-used in the right setting.

Literature:

Siegfried Gronert, Türdrücker der Moderne, eine Designgeschichte, W. König, Köln, 1991

Text and photographs © Room 606, 2013. All rights reserved.

name: A vintage Braun AB 313 rsl quartz alarm clock designed by Dietrich Lubs in 1990
description:
Braun model number 4783 
Measuring approximately 98 mm x 70 x 22

A classic Braun travel clock, designed by Lubs while working under the design directorship of Dieter Rams.
By this point in time the firm's analogue clock range's defining characteristics had become well established: the matte black casing, pared down dial and coloured hands (wide white hands for hours and minutes, narrow yellow for sweeping seconds hand and inconspicuous black hand with contrasting coloured point for the alarm setting) are present. The integral light and protective fold-down front cover with world time zones printed on the inside adds another dimension - to my mind even now it remains the ideal clock to take on your holidays.
This is the uncommon rsl variant - which means you only have to wave your hand in front to the clock to activate the snooze function.
With all elements designed to prioritise ease-of-use for the user, it's a fabulous example of Braun's timeless Bauhaus-tradition design.
The clock is in excellent vintage used condition - it's fully working with only very light surface handling marks and no damages.
Reference 
See Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, pp 473 for more information.

© Text and photographs copyright room_606 2013. All rights reserved.

name: ADO Speelgoed toy cart, designed by Ko Verzuu, c.1935
description:
Ado was a Dutch manufacturer of children's toys from the mid-1920s to the mid-1950s.

The earliest pieces, those made between 1925 and 1933, were constructed by tuberculosis patients at the Berg en Bosch sanatorium in Apeldoorn as a kind of occupational therapy.

Ado's designer was Ko Verzuu. His startlingly modern cars, trucks, building blocks, dolls houses and miniature pieces of furniture were greatly inspired by De Stijl and particularly Gerrit Rietveld.

The toys were relatively expensive - they retailed through the famous department stores Metz & Co and De Bijenkorf - and did not reach a mass audience.

However in more recent years they have attracted interest among collectors of twentieth century design, particularly after a major exhibition was held at the Museum Boymans-Van Beuningen, Rotterdam in 1994.

Size approx. 13 inches x 7 inches x 3 inches.

This is a rare find and I would describe the overall condition and good to very good. There is a little inconspicuous damage to  the underside (please see photos), but the colours are vibrant and it displays beautifully.

name: The Bauhaus and the Bauhaus Designers Christies 1989 | Bayer Gropius Dell Brandt Mondrian Mies
description:
THE BAUHAUS AND THE BAUHAUS DESIGNERS
 
Christie's Amsterdam
 
26 October 1989
 
English text
 
68 pages featuring 83 lots illustrated in colour or black and white
 
A brilliant early Twentieth Century design sale catalogue devoted to modernist design works by (both well- and lesser-known) Bauhaus students and teachers. The lots reflects the breadth of the school's output and include ceramics, metalware, furniture, glassware, books and works on paper and painting. This scarce reference will appeal in particular to collector and admirers of Christian Dell; alongside several works by him there are documents, design drawings and tools from the designer's estate.
 
Designers featured include:
 
Herbert Bayer
Gerd Balzer
Lena Reyer Bergner
Johannes Berthold
Marianne Brandt
Marcel Breuer
Christian Dell
Josef Hartwig
Wlihelm Wagenfeld
Lothar Schreyer
Marguerite Friedlander
Franz Erhlich
Laszlo Moholy-Nagy
Piet Mondrian
Paul Klee
Osklar Schlemmer
Albert Gleizes
Walter Gropius
Otto Lindig
Erich Mrozek
Petra Petitpierre
Hans Pryzembel
Karl Raichle
Otto Rittweger
Luidwig Mies Van Der Rohe
Joost Schmidt
and Wolfgang Tumpel
 
Condition: Excellent used condition with minimal signs of wear. It's very clean and bright with no inscriptions.

name: Original 1972 Braun Coiffeur set by Reinhold Weiss (BOXED)
description:
A vintage Braun Coiffeur set with Hairdryer HLD 3/31 (Model 4425) designed by Reinhold Weiss in 1972 (Boxed / MINT)

This vintage Braun piece recalls the first firm’s first hairdryer – the HLD 2, which Reinhold Weiss designed in 1964. 

Here the original rectangular rocker switch has been replaced with a less formal circular yellow button. This feature had been introduced by Dieter Rams in his iconic HLD 4 model in 1970. Furthermore, the cylindrical shape of the rear section mirrors the H 7 heater, which Weiss has co-designed with Rams in 1967. 

The Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) in New York holds eleven Reinhold Weiss items in its permanent collection, including the HLD 2 hairdryer.

This hairdryer comes in a boxed Coiffeur set that includes a pouch and original box, instructions card and guarantee leaflet. It is in absolutely mint / unused working condition. It's a truly fabulous find.

The hairdryer has a continental European 2-pin plug and has an integral voltage selector for 220 or 110 volts. There are several important things to note about functionality. 

Most importantly, all vintage electrical items are sold here as decorative items only and must be fully safety checked by a qualified electrician before being plugged into the mains, if you decide you want to use them. Please see my important condition of sale note covering all types of vintage electrical items below.
Secondly, following any safety check, it is important to note that the hair dryer would require an inexpensive socket adapter to be used outside continental Europe. They are definitely NOT intended for use with bathroom shaver sockets.
Furthermore, the items' functionality has been tested – for the buyer’s information only - on UK mains electricity supply. The selector for 110 volts was not tested. Prospective buyers from other countries must check with an electrician local to them to confirm safe compatibility. 


Reference
Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, pp 464 for more information.

name: Wolfgang Tümpel 1903 - 1978: Ein Bauhauskunstler aus Bielefeld
description:
Wolfgang Tumpel 1903 - 1978: Ein Bauhauskunstler aus Bielefeld 

Published by Museum Huelsmann, Bielefeld, Germany, 2003

Softcover

First Edition

96 pages, profusely illustrated with colour photographs of works

Text in German

Condition: Mint, as new.



A rare reference on one of the most overlooked designers of the Modern Movement. 

As member of the Staatliches Bauhaus metalwork department at Wiemar, Wolfgang Tümpel worked in close collaboration with modernist luminaries Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, Christian Dell, Marianne Brandt, Wilhelm Wagenfeld and Hans Przyrembel. 

He also collaborated with Oskar Schlemmer in the school's famously avantgarde theatre workshop. 

This extremely comprehensive book covers his output in chronological order from silverware and lighting executed at the Bauhaus to later work, including industrial design of the 1960s.

name: An ABW 35 wall clock by Dietrich Lubs for BRAUN, 1988
description:
The final piece in modernist wall clock range, developed by Lubs in the 1980s while he was working under the design directorship of Dieter Rams. 

As in the ABW 21 of a year earlier, the numerals are reduced to just four positions on the dial to promote instant readability from distance. The translucent tubular outer ring added a new dimension, introducing shifting visual elements of shadow and light into the design to dramatic visual effect. 

The clock is fully factory marked on the front of the dial: BRAUN quartz / Made in Germany and also on the quartz movement. The movement also has the clock's Braun product number, 4778.

It measures approx. 240 mm in diameter and approx 25 mm in depth, it is in excellent used condition and full working order. There are only the most minor signs of age and use - no damages or signs of repair. 

Reference

See Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, pages 239 and 474 for an illustration and more information.

name: Stacking ashtray set designed by Wilhelm Wagenfeld for WMF in 1951
description:
Comprising six trays in blue-green 'turmalin' glass inside a metal stand.

This striking piece was created for WMF in 1951 and produced as WMF model number 499.01 until 1973. 

It is a perfect expression of Wagenfeld's contribution to the Bauhaus tradition; inexpensive, everyday and rigorously functional.  

This example is in excellent used condition with minimal signs of age and use but no significant damages. Please see the pictures.  
 
Approx. height 140 mm.

name: A vintage T 2 Cylindric cigarette lighter, designed by Dieter Rams for Braun, West Germany, 1968
description:
Cylindrical form in silver plated case with rare relief grid pattern detailing with moulded black plastic button and base


Approx 8 cm in height


The T2, which made use of a new magnetic ignition technology, was reportedly one of Rams's favourite creations. Its sculptural simplicity makes it is a  fabulous example of Braun's Bauhaus-tradition, Ulm School design and it's an incredibly pleasing item to operate.

There's an example held in the permanent collection of design at the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA), New York (see link below) and examples featured in the Rams retrospective titled 'Less and More' that was held at the Design Museum, London, between November 2009 and March this year.

This silver-plated example is an exceptional find. 

It is in very good used condition with only minor surface wear consistent with age and use but no significant damages. It has been tested and works without leaking gas. 


References:
MoMA website: http://www.moma.org/collection/object.php?object_id=4599
See Treadway Auction Gallery, 20th Century Art and Design sale, 6 March 2005, lot number 1195.

name: Bart van der Leck 1876-1958 | De Stijl
description:
Rare exhibition catalogue providing a detailed and well illustrated biography of the De Stijl co-founder, artist and designer.

Rijksmuseum Kröller-Müller (Otterlo, Netherlands) and Stedelijk Museum, Amsterdam, 1976

28 x 21 cms

Softcover

Unpaginated (approx 80 pages)

Text in Dutch and English



Very good condition

name: An Important Collection of Works by Bart van der Leck from the Estate of the Artist
description:
Christie's, Amsterdam, 4 December 2001 
 
This is a truly unique, extremely hard to find catalogue illustrating an important collection from the estate of the De Stijl artist and designer. 

It features 58 lots, all fully illustrated and is in excellent condition with only minor signs of use and no inscriptions. Don't miss this opportunity to acquire an extremely rare modernist art and design reference.

The catalogue is in very used condition with only minor signs of use. Internally is very clean and bright.

name: A black Oxford leather and chrome TFG 1 Permanent Table Lighter by Reinhold Weiss for Braun, 1965
description:
Dating from 1965, the TFG 1 was the company’s first lighter and quickly attracted the alternative moniker 'the toaster', for visually obvious reasons. The sliding switch mechanism was a design innovation at the time.

It was created by Reinhold Weiss, then working under the design directorship of Dieter Rams. Weiss was the designer of several landmark Braun pieces of this period, including the HL 1 desk fan and HUV 1 sun lamp, both of which are represented in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA), New York.

The piece is marked Braun permanent, Made in West Germany on the underside.  It measures approximately 105mm long by 32mm wide and 75 mm high and takes a type of fuel - gas - that's still very commonly available today.

It’s in very good vintage cosmetic condition.  It has only minor surface signs of use consistent with decades of careful use – there are no deep scratches, cracks or signs of repair. 

The mechanism sparks and the lighter works, usually on the second click. Because vintage items can go wrong at any time, it is being sold here as a display item only.

In all, a wonderful example of 1960s Braun design. This model was only produced for two years and is correspondingly hard to find.

References
See Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, p 257 and 476 for an illustration and more information.


© Text and photographs copyright room_606 (2013).

name: Original poster stamp by Peter Behrens for the 1914 Deutsche Werkbund exhibition
description:
An original poster stamp advertising the landmark Deutscher Werkbund Exhibition of 1914, designed by Peter Behrens

The Deutsche Werkbund (DWB) was a group founded by Peter Behrens and Josef Hoffmann among others to promote the marriage of artistic endeavour with mass production. 

They went on to exert enormous influence in the progress of modernist design and functionalism, particularly in the formation of the Bauhaus.

Their famous Cologne Exhibition of 1914 included Walter Gropius' steel and glass model factory, Bruno Taut's Glashaus (Glass Pavilion) and Henry Van Der Velde's Werkbund Theatre.

Size approx 2.25 inches x 1.75 inches

A great find.


Condition: Excellent unused condition. Very clean and bright with no marks with perforations intact on all four sides (not seen on scan).

name: Art et Décoration | Periodical on modern design, art and architecture | 7 individual issues
description:
Art et Décoration

Revue Mensuelle d'Art Moderne

Editions Albert Lévy, Librairie Centrale des Beaux-Arts, Paris

A collection of 7 individual issues:

March 1928

August 1928

September 1928

October 1928

November 1928

December 1928

April 1931

All in very good condition indeed except from August 1928, which has some wear along the spine, causing the cover to become partially detached.

name: A rare dark grey HL 1 Multiwind table fan (Reinhold Weiss for Braun, 1959/60)
description:
Despite what’s often printed in the reference books, the HL 1 or Multiwind table fan was designed by Reinhold Weiss in the winter of 1959-60, a full two years before Dieter Rams become director of the firm’s legendary Design Department.

It’s a particularly ingenious design, using a spinning slotted cylinder to produce a surprisingly strong gust of cool air in two optional speed settings.

To my mind, despite being more than 50 years old, it beats hands down modern fans of the same size.

The dark grey example I’m offering here is quite rare - it is far more commonly found in light grey.

There is a HL 1 in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA), New York.

The fan is housed in plastic and steel casing and has a clear plastic guard with the Braun company logo in red. It measures approximately 140 mm x 140 mm x 70 mm. It is mains operated and has a standard European 2-pin plug. Please note that the item’s functionality has been tested on the European mains electricity supply (220 V ~ /50 Hz) – others please check with an electrician local to you to confirm functionality. The wiring is original. All vintage electrical items must be safety checked by a qualified electrician before use. Please see my important note about the sale of vintage electrical items below.

This example is in very good vintage used condition and working. It has some minor surface marking here and there consistent with use, but no significant damages such as cracks to the casing or signs of repair. 

An iconic, early Braun piece.

name: BAUHAUS 1919 - 1928 Edited by Herbert Bayer, Walter Gropius and Ise Gropius
description:
Charles T. Branford Company, Boston, USA, 1959 (third printing)


A copy of this scarce and important book on the great German art and design movement, by two of the key protagonists themselves.

Originally published in 1938 for an exhibition at the New York Museum Of Modern Art, the book gives information and text on all the courses taught, and the important artists who taught there.

This extremely authoritative and comprehensive work is illustrated with 550 black and white photos of examples of the work in all media, including painting, scupture, pottery, furniture, graphics etc. along with biographical material and historical documents.

It includes work by Walter Gropius, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, Paul Klee, Wassily Kandinsky, Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, Marcel Breuer, Herbert Bayer, Lyonel Feininger, Oskar Schlemmer, Josef Albers, Hannes Meyer, Anni Albers, Otti Berger, Gunta Stolzl and Max Bill among many others.

The book retains its fabulous Herbert Bayer-designed dust jacket. Internally the condition is very good  pages are very clean and bright and there are no inscriptions. There is some foxing on the page edges. The blue cloth covered boards, complete with Bayer typography - are also very well preserved. The rare dust jacket has several issues - please see the multiple pictures I have provided. The book measures approximately 22.5 cm by 29cm.

name: Vintage bottle opener attributed to Carl Aubock, Austria, c.1950
description:
A wonderful sculptural bottle opener, strongly attributed to the Austrian designer Carl Auböck.

It is made of stainless Steel, with teak grips and brass rivets.

Measuring approximately 8 inches in length, it is in very good well used condition, with some minor marks and imperfections consistent with regular use but no significant damages or signs of restoration. Still a wonderful everyday, functional object.

It will made a stunning authentic accessory for any mid-century modern interior.



Text and photos Copyright © Matthew Grice 2013

name: Hammered pewter cream and sugar set, Karl Raichle, c. 1935
description:
Karl Raichle was a student at the Dessau Bauhaus while the metalwork department was being run by László Moholy-Nagy.

Owing to leftist activism in his youth, Raichle was twice forced to relocate during the rise of the National Socialists.

His pieces - invariably executed in pewter, copper or brass - are usually signed Meersburg, the town on Lake Constance where he was able to set up in business after 1933. Here he enjoyed the artistic influence of his friend the abstract painter Julius Bissier.

For further reading see:

Dedo von Kerssenbrock-Krosigk (ed), The Modern Art of Metalwork (1889-1939), Bröhan State Museum of Art Nouveau, Art Deco and Functionalism, Berlin, 2001.

Christie's Amsterdam, The Bauhaus and the Bauhaus Designers, 26 October 1989.

Condition: Very good indeed with some minor knocks to the metal but no significant damages. A wonderful rare find.

name: Oil! Vol. 2 by Upton Sinclair with cover by Ladislav SUTNAR, 1931
description:
Petrolej! 2 (Oil! Vol. II) by Upton Sinclair

Published by Druzstevní práce (DP), Prague, 1931. 

Softcover, with original pictorial wraps designed by Ladislav Sutnar

308 pages 

Text in Czech




This stunning book design comes from the famous Upton Sinclair DP book series and is described in Ladislav Sutnar – Prague - New York - Design in Action as being “among the greatest successes of the publishing industry of the 1930s”.

Druzstevní práce (in English, Co-operative work) was a subscription based Czech publishing house that had gained popularity among the Czech middle classes in the 1920s for its consciously forward looking stance. Sutnar become its principle art director in 1929, bringing his visionary approach to design to bear on all aspects of its output.

His startlingly innovative book jacket designs included the pioneering use of photomontage and  photographic detail inspired by Hollywood cinematography. 

As the Victoria & Albert Museum states in its Modernism microsite, Sutnar played a very key role in the emergence of Modernism, but has been widely overlooked outside Eastern Europe. His original designs are rarely offered for sale. This is a very rare opportunity to acquire an important piece of design history with clear investment potential.

For more information on him, see the V&A's biography here:

http://www.vam.ac.uk/vastatic/microsites/1331_modernism/artist_92_bio.html

 

References

For illustrations see:

Ladislav Sutnar – Prague - New York - Design in Action, Iva Janakova and Stephen Heller (eds), Museum of Decorative Arts in Prague and Argo Publishers, Prague, 2003, p. 75,  Illustration number 101.

Druzstevni prace – Sutnar Sudek, Lucie Vickova (ed), u(p)m, Prague, 2007, p.40


Condition

The overall condition is very good. This is a very fragile publication and I would rate this as an excellent survivor. Internally it is clean and there are no previous owner inscriptions. The binding is fragile though sound and the page edges are a little dusty. The all important wraps are very good, though a little yellowed and slightly worns at the edges and fragile at the spine. It is well protected within a mylar cover.

name: DAS NEUE FRANKFURT: NEUES BAUEN, NEUES GESTALTEN | New Buildings, New Forms
description:
NEUES BAUEN, NEUES GESTALTEN (New Buildings, New Forms)
Das Neue Frankfurt / Die Neue Stadt
Ein Zeitschrift zwischen 1926 und 1933

Heinz Hirdina

Dresden Verlag der Kunst, 1984

Hardback with cloth boards and pictorial dust jacket

First Edition

392 pages, profusely illustrated

Approx 22 cm x 19 cm

Text in German



Scarce monograph on the modernist architecture and design periodical Das Neue Frankfurt. 

In reproducing much of the original periodical it's packed full of archive photos, articles and original advertisements, placing Bauhaus era buildings and design in its original context. 

Designers and manufacturers with work featured include Christian Dell, Marianne Brandt, Thonet, the Fuld telephone, Margarete Schütte-Lihotzky's Frankfurt kitchen, Ferdinand Kramer, Gerrit Thomas Rietveld, J.J.P. Oud, Louis Poulsen, Poul Henningsen, Marcel Breuer among many others. 

The book is itself a typographical joy, reflecting the avant-garde design and layout of the original periodical.

The overall condition is very good indeed with only very minor signs of age and use. Internally it is excellent; very clean and bright with sound binding. The dust jacket has a 2.5 cm tear on the bottom edge but is otherwise very good.

name: Braun Tonarmwaage, Dieter Rams, 1962
description:
The Tonarmwaage, literally 'sound arm scale' in English, was designed by Dieter Rams in 1962.
One of the most scarce of all vintage Braun items, it is a tool for calculating the ideal balance for a stylus on a record player.
It's arguably the perfect expression of Rams' and Braun's practical minimalism.
Condition: Excellent
Reference: The Tonarmwaage was featured on the cover of Wallpaper magazine in October 2007 when Dieter Rams was invited to guest-edit the magazine.

name: Freiräume Houses That Made History Modernist Architecture Le Corbusier Aalto Gropius FLW
description:
Freiräume. Häuser, die Geschichte machten 1920 bis 1940

Christopher Holz and Andreas Tonnesmann, Guillemette Morel-Journel, Dietrich Worbs, Ita Heinze-Greenberg, Tilo Richter, Peter Reed, Bruno Maurer.

Published by HypoVereinsbank, Munich, Germany, 1998

First Edition 

Hardcover in white boards, no DJ (as issued). 

Condition fine inside, covers with light spots. 

215 mm x 215 mm 

168 pages

Profusely illustrated in colour and black and white

German text


A wonderful scarce German text focussing on seven landmark houses of the Modern Movement.

The buildings featured are:

Villa Savoye by Le Corbusier
The Muller House by Adolf Loos
The Rupenhorn House by Erich Mendelsohn
The Schminke House by Hans Scharoun
Fallingwater by Frank Lloyd Wright
Villa Mairea by Alvar Aalto and  The Gropius House in Lincoln Massachusetts by the founder of the Bauhaus, Walter Gropius.  

Very good condition indeed.

© Text and photographs by room_606. All rights reserved.

name: A vintage Braun Diskus torch designed by Hans Gugelot in 1964
description:
A vintage Braun Diskus torch designed by Hans Gugelot in 1964. Issued in 1970
Braun model number 904
Plastic 
Size approx 70 mm in diameter


I find it hard to believe that this scarce Braun item was designed as early as 1964, such is the timeless quality of the design.
In fact it was not actually released until after its creator had died. Hans Gugelot, who passed away in 1965, had been a lecturer at the Ulm School of Design and a key figure in the early collaboration between the School and Braun. 
He co-designed two milestone Braun pieces - the SK 4 record player with Dieter Rams in 1956 and the Sixtant shaver with Gerd Alfred Mueller in 1961 and was regarded by Erwin Braun as "the actual creator of Braun Design" with Otl Aicher (see p 500 reference below).
It’s in mint original condition and works (using 2 LR1 batteries - not included). As you can see it comes complete with original box.

Reference:
See Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, pp 262, 478 and 500 for illustrations and more information

name: The Viennese Chair: The story of Bentwood Furniture
description:
La Seggiola di Vienna: Storia dei mobili in legno curvato
The Viennese Chair: The story of Bentwood Furniture

Giovanna Massobrio and Paolo Portoghesi 

Published by Martano Editore, Torino, Italy, No date given (1980?)

Hardcover in dustjacket

Size 8 inches square mundus j & j kohn josef hoffmann wiener werkstatte adolf loos fledermaus

321 pages with myriad illustrations of chairs. Includes a complete reproduction of the Thonet 1904 furniture trade catalog (126 pages). Parts of trade catalogs of other firms are also reproduced.

Text in Italian with English summary at the end titled 'Thonet and the history of bent wood techniques'. 


In my opinion this extremely rare book is one of the best visual references available on the art nouveau bentwood furniture in general and Thonet chairs in particular. The reproduced catalogue is an invaluable resource, further supplemented by a great many more illustrations of the chairs, both in vintage and recent photographs, as well as drawings in the text. At the time of writing i could not find another copy of this book advertised for sale anywhere on the internet and I'm highly unlikely to be able to offer another one for sale any time soon. Don't miss this opportunity.

Condition: This is a very good copy in a very good dust jacket. It is very clean both inside and out with just expected signs of age and use. The spine is faded and there is a little scuffing to the edges of the dust jacket. there are no previous owner inscriptions and it is not price-clipped.

name: THIRTIES | British Art and Design Before the War | 1979 Hayward Gallery catalogue
description:
Thirties. British Art and Design Before the War

Arts Council of Great Britain, 1979 

270x210mm 

320 pages with index. 

Illustrated mainly in black and white, some colour. 


Important and profusely illustrated catalogue charting British art and design prior to the Second World War. 

Published to accompany the major exhibition at the Hayward Gallery, London between 25 October 1979 and 13 January 1980. 

This is a fabulous reference work for collectors and historians, featuring sections on art, architecture, prints and book illustration, furniture, textiles, ceramics and glass, studio pottery, silverwork and jewellery, stained glass, transport and photography. 

Modern architecture obsessives will value the section on the Modern Movement in Britain. There's a great colour picture of Lubetkin's penguin pool at Regent's Park Zoo.

Index of illustrated designers and manufacturers includes..Aalto, Ardizzone, Bacon, Baillie Scott, Barnsley, Bawden, Behrens, Vanessa Bell, Marcel Breuer, Blackie, Alberto Cavalcanti, Chermayeff, Wells Coates, E.K. Cole, Curwen Press, Doulton ...you get the idea! 

Condition: Very good +

name: Female nude by Jaromir Funke, 1940
description:
A gelatin silver print from the folio 'Akt V Ceske Fotografii'(the Nude in Czech Photography), published by Orbis, Prague in 1967

Size: 125 x 175 mm approx.

Unframed

Condition: Very good +

Jaromír Funke was one of the leading Czech photographic artists of the 1920s and 1930s. He founded the Czech Photographic Society with Josef Sudek and Adolf Schneeberger in 1924. 

He also directed the photography department at the School of Arts and Crafts, Bratislava and was the editor of the magazine Fotografický obzor (Photographic Horizons).

name: Bauhaus Furniture: A Legend Reviewed
description:
Bauhaus-Möbel: Eine Legende wird besichtigt / Bauhaus-Furniture /A Legend Reviewed

Bauhaus-Archiv Museum für Gestaltung, Berlin, Germany 2003

Taschenbuch (235 mm x 165 mm approx.)

349 pages, profusely illustrated in colour and black and white

Text in GERMAN and ENGLISH

Condition: Very good +

Rare exhibition catalogue, probably the most authoritative and comprehensive on the subject. Hard to find.

name: Marks and Monograms | The Decorative Arts 1880 - 1960 | Malcolm Haslam
description:
MARKS AND MONOGRAMS The Decorative Arts 1880 - 1960
An invaluable collector's guide featuring 2000 makers and designers from Britain, Europe and North America

By Malcolm Haslam

Published by Lutterworth Press, Guildford, England, 1995

First Edition (NB this is a revised and much expanded version of Haslam's earlier title Marks and Monograms of the Modern Movement, which covered up to 1930).

Hardcover in black publishers' cloth, with dustjacket

Condition: Excellent, with minimal signs of use. 

 
Unique and absolutely invaluable, this comprehensive volume encompasses the Arts and Crafts period, Art Nouveau and Jugendstil, the Vienna Secession, the Wiener Werkstätte, the Bauhaus, De Stijl and the early Modern Movement, European and North American Art Deco and American and Scandinavian mid-Century modernism.

The volume covers everything from Augustus Pugin, Thomas Seddon, and Christopher Dresser to Liberty & Co, WMF, Eric Ravillious, Josef Hoffmann, Vally Wieselthier and Jean Puiforcat to St Ives Pottery, Charles Eames, Le Corbusier, Gio Ponti, Old Hall and Tapio Wirkkala! Among the famous names are innumerable lesser-known ones, making this a truly unsurpassed tool for researching the identity of an unknown maker's signature, monogram or mark.

The book's 448 pages illustrate over 2000 marks and monograms, arranged by type and country. There are separate chapters on ceramics, glass, metalwork and jewellery, graphics, furniture and textiles. The information is then ordered by country in each category.

The countries covered are Britain, USA, France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany, Austria, Italy, Scandinavia, Russia (the former Soviet Union), Switzerland and Spain.

With full cross-referenced index of all artists, designers and manufacturers featured.

A must-have reference for collectors, dealers and enthusiasts. Now out-of-print and very scarce.

AMONG THE DESIGNERS / MANUFACTURERS FEATURED IN THE BOOK ARE: William Morris, Guild of Handicraft, Charles Rennie Mackintosh, Jacques Adnet, Kaj Franck, Ginori, Gio Ponti, Alphonse Mucha, Bruno Paul, Emil Orlik, Albin Muller, William Moorcroft, William de Morgan, Osiris, Koloman Moser, Dagobert Peche, Otto Prutscher, Charles Voysey, Wilhelm Wagenfeld, Bretby Art Pottery, Jean Dunand, Carl Otto Czeschka, Dallas Pottery, Theo van Doesburg, Doulton, Delft, Carlton Ware, Gebruder Thonet, Jan Bontjes van Beek, Adolf Bohm Kay Bojesen, Theodor Bogler, Otto Lindig, Burmantofts Faience, Gustav Klimt, Orrefors, Karhula, Kayzerzinn, Eliel Saarinen, Timo Sarpaneva, Jutta Sika, Gustav Stickley, Henry Tooth, Jan Toorop, Villeroy und Boch, Otto Wagner, Zsolnay, Piet Zwart, Werkstatte Hagenauer, Werkstaette Kate Greenaway, Walter Gropius, Christian Dell, Gerrit Thomas Rietveld, Michael Powolny, Nanna Ditzel, Heal, Isokon, W.A.S. Benson, Peter Behrens, Marcel Breuer,  Le Corbusier, Frank Brangwyn, Heal, Gillow, Betty Joel,  Gordon Russell, Waring and Gillow, Donald Deskey, Herman Miller, Roycroft, Georg Jensen,  Henning Koppel,  Henry van der Velde, Henri van der Velde among many others.

name: Original Peter Behrens poster stamp for AEG, ca. 1910
description:
Rare original poster stamps depicting electrical products designed by Peter Behrens for AEG.

It's no exaggeration to describe Peter Behrens' appointment as artistic director of AEG in 1907 as a turning point in design history; it was the first time a major international company had employed a single designer to advise on all aspects of its corporate identity, accommodation and output. 

Besides creating new premises for the company - including the Turbine Factory, itself a landmark of modernism - he devised a new range of ground-breaking and consciously forward-looking domestic and industrial electrical products, including lighting, clocks, table fans and tea kettles.

Size approx. 40 mm x 62 mm

The sale -  a selection of items belonging to the internationally renowned collector Torsten Brohan - was one of the first of its kind to be held by a major international auction house and remains a benchmark in terms of the quality and importance of the items on offer.  Brohan has specialised for more than twenty years in Bauhaus, Russian Constructivism and the international design avant-garde and has worked with many museums worldwide in arranging exhibitions and assisting with acquisitions.

name: A pair of modernist door handles originally designed by Hans Poelzig [1 of 4 pairs available]
description:
These striking period door handles were specifically designed for the administrative offices of the giant I.G. Farben paint factory in Frankfurt.

The building, completed in 1931, was the work of the architect, painter and set designer Hans Poelzig.

One of the progenitors of the Modern Movement, Poelzig participated in the first major International Style project, the 1927 Die Wohnung expo.

The event saw the construction of an entire estate of modernist dwellings in the elevated Weissenhof suburb of Stuttgart.

Poelzig contributed a prototype single family house alongside Le Corbusier, Mies van der Rohe, Gropius and Behrens among others.

His imposing I.G. Farben building still stands and has become the centrepiece of the Goethe University campus in Frankfurt. Poelzig died in 1936, aged 67.

The nickel-plated aluminium door handles I'm offering here are of later manufacture, probably the early 1950s. They retain their original rectangular lock plates.

They are in excellent used condition with expected signs of use, but no significant damages. They will look fabulous given a new lease of life in the right setting.

This is one of 4 pairs I have available. Please contact me if you would like to purchase the set.


Literature:

Siegfried Gronert, Türdrücker der Moderne, eine Designgeschichte, W. König, Köln, 1991

Text and photographs © Room 606, 2013. All rights reserved.

name: Hordubal by Karel Capek with photomontage book design by Frantisek Muzika, 1935
description:
Hordubal by Karel Capek

Published by Fr. Borovy, Prague, Czechoslovakia, 1935

Softcover in pictorial wraps

Size appox. 21.5 x 14 cm

Bookjacket designed by the Devetsil artist / designer Frantisek Muzika

Wonderful groundbreaking photomontage book design by one of the key figures of the Czech avant-garde of the 1930s.

Devetsil was at the centre of the Czech art scene of the period; besides Muzika its members included Karel Tiege, Jaroslav Seifert, Adolf Hoffmeister, Vitezslav Nezval, Konstantin Biebl, Otakar Mrkvicka, Jindrich Styrsky and Toyen.

It was responsible for publishing the several important theorizing periodicals and almanacs – among them ReD (Revue Devětsilu), Devětsil and Život.

References:
For illustrations of similar Muzika book-jackets from Muzika's Jihoslovanská Knihovna series, see:  Toman, J. The Modern Czech Book. Photo/Montage in Print. Prague 2009, page 200.

Also see Zdenek Primus, Tschechische Avantgarde 1922 - 1940, p 152 for an illustration of Mukiza's cover for Obycejny (1935), which was also by Karel Capek and part of the same series. The third and final title in the series was Povetron (1940).

Condition:

This rare piece of original groundbreaking book design is a very fragile publication and I would rate it as an good survival. The binding is fragile and the roughly cut page edges are a little dusty. There are some loose pages that do not appear to have been bound in at publication. The all important cover is very good indeed - though as you would expect a little worn at the edges and spine - and it displays beautifully.

name: Modernist door handles by Ferdinand Kramer for the New Frankfurt, c.1926
description:
A pair of door handles designed by Ferdinand Kramer, c.1926

These door handles were created for 'The New Frankfurt' in the mid-1920s.

Kramer had attended the Bauhaus for a year, before leaving to collaborate on May's project to create new settlements of affordable social housing in Frankfurt.

May aimed to mobilise the emerging modernist architectural idiom - using the latest materials and construction methods - to address an acute housing shortage in the city. This had been caused by the economic crises that had gripped Germany in the aftermath of the First World War. 

Kramer was also a contributor to the second C.I.A.M. conference, which was held in Frankfurt in 1929 and was focused on promoting functionalism in architecture through an evaluation of May's work. 

In 1938 Kramer emigrated to the United States and soon began work on a number of design projects, including  a collaboration with the visionary Norman Bel Geddes on designs for the 1939 World's Fair in New York. 

He also had connections with the social theorists of the Frankfurt School and worked on commissions from Theodor Adorno at Institute for Social Research during its tenure in New York.

He returned to Germany in 1947, holding the post of director of the Johann Wolfgang Goethe University of Frankfurt am Main until his retirement in 1962.

Materials: Nickel plated metal complete with original rectangular lock plates.

Condition:Extremely good used condition with no significant damages, just expected surface wear reflecting decades of age and use. 

References: Berthold Lubetkin used Kramer's handles for his terrace of four houses at Genesta Road, London in 1933-4.

** MORE QUANTITIES CAN BE SOURCED ON REQUEST. SEE ALSO GROPIUS AND MEYER HANDLES

Text and photographs © Room 606, 2013. All rights reserved.

name: William De Morgan | Pre-Raphaelite Ceramics | First US Edition 1971
description:
William De Morgan
Pre-Raphaelite Ceramics

By William Gaunt & M D E Clayton-Stamm

Published by De Morgan Foundation, New York Graphic Society Ltd, 1971

First Edition

Hardcover with blue cloth boards and pictorial dustjacket

176 pages with myriad illustrations in black and white and colour


This rare book is an excellent monograph on one of the most important figures in the British Arts and Crafts movement. De Morgan was a long time friend of and collaborator with William Morris and he designed tiles, stained glass and furniture for Morris & Co. from 1863 to 1872.

This comprehensive book includes detailed account of De Morgan's career and is profusely illustrated with examples of his work. There's an invaluable pictorial summary of De Morgan pottery marks, a full list of bibliographical references and a detailed index at the rear.

De Morgan's work is extremely highly prized by collectors worldwide and this an essential reference for collectors, dealers and enthusiasts.

Condition: The book is in very good condition. Internally it is excellent. The binding is tight and the pages are extremely bright and clean with no inscriptions. There is some wear to the dust cover, which is now protected within a mylar cover. There several chips and tears to the top. It has not been price-clipped.

name: Tone Seliskar, Na úskali | Czech avant-garde book design by Frantisek MUZIKA, 1938
description:
Tone Seliskar, Na úskali, L. Mazác, Prague 1938

The scarce fourth volume from the Jihoslovanská Knihovna (South Slavic Library) with covers designed by Frantisek Muzika, 1938.

Truly ground-breaking photo-montage book design by the Devetsil artist and designer Frantisek Muzika, one of the key figures of the Czech avant-garde of the 1920s and 30s. 

Devetsil was at the centre of the Czech art scene of the period; besides Muzika its members also included Karel Tiege, Jaroslav Seifert, Adolf Hoffmeister, Vitezslav Nezval, Konstantin Biebl, Otakar Mrkvicka, Jindrich Styrsky and Toyen. It was responsible for publishing the several important theorizing periodicals and almanacs – among them ReD (Revue Devětsilu), Devětsil and Život. 

I would describe the overall condition as good to very good. The binding is fragile and the roughly cut page edges are dusty. The all important cover, though a little yellowed and worn at the edges is very good and displays beautifully.

References: Toman, J. The Modern Czech Book. Photo/Montage in Print. Prague 2009, page 200

name: A KSM 1/11 Aromatic Coffee Grinder by Reinhold Weiss for Braun AG, West Germany, 1966
description:
The KSM 1/11 coffee grinder was created by Reinhold Weiss, who was deputy to Braun Design Director Dieter Rams between 1962 and 1967. 

It’s a landmark piece of Braun design. The focus is on the machine’s control – a single bright red button – that echoes the austere simplicity of the cylindrical form but appears shocking against the white plastic casing. It’s also an extremely pleasing device to handle and operate.

In their book Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer describe it as a “minimalist monument” and “the simplest object yet to bear the Braun logo” (see below for reference).

Weiss was the designer of several important Braun products - including the TFG 1 table lighter, HLD 2 hair dryer and the HL 1 and HL 70 desk fans and the Museum of Modern Art in New York has no fewer than eleven of his creations for the firm in its permanent collection.
The grinder is mains operated and has a standard European 2-pin plug. Please note that the item’s functionality has been tested on the European mains electricity supply (220 V) – others please check with an electrician local to you to confirm functionality. The wiring is original. 

Please note that all vintage electrical items are sold here as decorative items only and must be fully safety checked by a qualified electrician before being plugged into the mains, if you decide you want to use them. Please see my important condition of sale note covering all types of vintage electrical items below. 

This example is in good but well-used condition - everything still works as it should but it has clearly seen many years of service. The white housing is in very good condition overall with light surface marks here and there but no significant damages. The plexiglass cover has become a little clouded over time and there is damage to its bottom edge, which is is only visible when the cover is removed for cleaning. This does not impact upon its visual appeal or function.


Reference
See Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, pages 382, 383, 447 and 496 for multiple illustrations and more information.

name: HL 1 Multiwind Electric Table Fan
description:
A HL 1 Multiwind Electric Table Fan by Reinhold Weiss for Braun AG, West Germany, 1961

Like the TFG 1 lighter I listed recently, the Multiwind table fan was conceived by Reinhold Weiss under the design directorship of Dieter Rams. It's a particularly ingenious design, using a spinning slotted cylinder to produce a surprisingly strong gust of cool air in two optional speed settings. To my mind, despite being a full 50 years old, it is far more effective than modern fans of the same size. The stand can be removed, allowing it to be operated upright, on its cylindrical base. There is a HL 1 in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA), New York.

The fan is housed in a light grey plastic and steel casing and has a clear plastic guard with the Braun company logo in red. It measures approximately 140 mm x 140 mm x 70 mm. It is mains operated and has a standard European 2-pin plug. Please note that the item’s functionality has been tested on the European mains electricity supply (220 V ~ /50 Hz) – others please check with an electrician local to you to confirm functionality. The wiring is original. All vintage electrical items must be safety checked by a qualified electrician before use. Please see my important note about the sale of vintage electrical items below.

This example is in very good vintage used condition and working. It has some minor handling marks here and their consistent with decades of careful use, but no significant damages such as cracks to the casing or signs of repair. Don't miss this iconic, early Braun piece.

For more Braun design items please see my other listings or email me via the link below the description.

 

Reference

Also see Bernd Polster and Olaf Meyer, Braun 50 Jahre Produktinnovation, DuMont Press, Cologne, Germany, 2005, p 436 for an illustration and more information.

name: MODERN ART OF METALWORK Catalogue for the Bröhan Museum of Art Nouveau, Art Deco and Functionalism
description:
MODERN ART OF METALWORK

Bröhan Museum: State Museum of Art Nouveau, Art Deco and Functionalism (1889-1939), Berlin

Broehan Museum, Berlin, 2001

Dedo von Kerssenbrock-Krosigk (Chief Editor)

Hard cover in colour pictorial covers (without dust jacket as issued).

Size: 10 3/4 x 9 inches approx

Pages: 598 with 495 illustrative plates (the vast majority in colour).

Text in ENGLISH


An invaluable resource for collectors and dealers, this hard-to-find and weighty tome illustrates surely one of the very finest collections of Art Nouveau, Art Deco and Modern Movement (including Bauhaus) metalwork to be found anywhere.

It includes detailed analysis of works by the Wiener Werkstatte, Gustave Serrurier-Bovy, Georg Jensen, Peter Behrens, Erhard & Sohne, Eduard Hueck, Orivit, Karl Raichle, Hans Przyrembel, Osiris, Edgar Brandt, Christofle, Desny, Jean Dunand, Jean Emile Puiforcat, Charles Robert Ashbee and the Guild of Handicraft, WAS Benson, Christopher Dresser, Liberty, Jan Eisenloeffel, Hagenauer, Hallberg, Russel Wright and the Chase Brass and Copper Company and Henry van de Velde among many others.

Includes artists' biographies, illustrated marks and bibliographic references.

Condition: MINT (as new)
